51def _process_plot_format(fmt): 

52 """ 

53 Process a MATLAB style color/line style format string. Return a 

54 (*linestyle*, *color*) tuple as a result of the processing. Default 

55 values are ('-', 'b'). Example format strings include: 

56 

57 * 'ko': black circles 

58 * '.b': blue dots 

59 * 'r--': red dashed lines 

60 * 'C2--': the third color in the color cycle, dashed lines 

61 

62 .. seealso:: 

63 

64 :func:`~matplotlib.Line2D.lineStyles` and 

65 :func:`~matplotlib.pyplot.colors` 

66 for all possible styles and color format string. 

67 """ 

68 

69 linestyle = None 

70 marker = None 

71 color = None 

72 

73 # Is fmt just a colorspec? 

74 try: 

75 color = mcolors.to_rgba(fmt) 

76 

77 # We need to differentiate grayscale '1.0' from tri_down marker '1' 

78 try: 

79 fmtint = str(int(fmt)) 

80 except ValueError: 

81 return linestyle, marker, color # Yes 

82 else: 

83 if fmt != fmtint: 

84 # user definitely doesn't want tri_down marker 

85 return linestyle, marker, color # Yes 

86 else: 

87 # ignore converted color 

88 color = None 

89 except ValueError: 

90 pass # No, not just a color. 

91 

92 # handle the multi char special cases and strip them from the 

93 # string 

94 if fmt.find('--') >= 0: 

95 linestyle = '--' 

96 fmt = fmt.replace('--', '') 

97 if fmt.find('-.') >= 0: 

98 linestyle = '-.' 

99 fmt = fmt.replace('-.', '') 

100 if fmt.find(' ') >= 0: 

101 linestyle = 'None' 

102 fmt = fmt.replace(' ', '') 

103 

104 chars = [c for c in fmt] 

105 

106 i = 0 

107 while i < len(chars): 

108 c = chars[i] 

109 if c in mlines.lineStyles: 

110 if linestyle is not None: 

111 raise ValueError( 

112 'Illegal format string "%s"; two linestyle symbols' % fmt) 

113 linestyle = c 

114 elif c in mlines.lineMarkers: 

115 if marker is not None: 

116 raise ValueError( 

117 'Illegal format string "%s"; two marker symbols' % fmt) 

118 marker = c 

119 elif c in mcolors.get_named_colors_mapping(): 

120 if color is not None: 

121 raise ValueError( 

122 'Illegal format string "%s"; two color symbols' % fmt) 

123 color = c 

124 elif c == 'C' and i < len(chars) - 1: 

125 color_cycle_number = int(chars[i + 1]) 

126 color = mcolors.to_rgba("C{}".format(color_cycle_number)) 

127 i += 1 

128 else: 

129 raise ValueError( 

130 'Unrecognized character %c in format string' % c) 

131 i += 1 

132 

133 if linestyle is None and marker is None: 

134 linestyle = rcParams['lines.linestyle'] 

135 if linestyle is None: 

136 linestyle = 'None' 

137 if marker is None: 

138 marker = 'None' 

139 

140 return linestyle, marker, color

143class _process_plot_var_args(object): 

144 """ 

145 Process variable length arguments to the plot command, so that 

146 plot commands like the following are supported:: 

147 

148 plot(t, s) 

149 plot(t1, s1, t2, s2) 

150 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2) 

151 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2, 'r--', t3, e3) 

152 

153 an arbitrary number of *x*, *y*, *fmt* are allowed 

154 """ 

155 def __init__(self, axes, command='plot'): 

156 self.axes = axes 

157 self.command = command 

158 self.set_prop_cycle() 

159 

160 def __getstate__(self): 

161 # note: it is not possible to pickle a itertools.cycle instance 

162 return {'axes': self.axes, 'command': self.command} 

163 

164 def __setstate__(self, state): 

165 self.__dict__ = state.copy() 

166 self.set_prop_cycle() 

167 

168 def set_prop_cycle(self, *args, **kwargs): 

169 if not (args or kwargs) or (len(args) == 1 and args[0] is None): 

170 prop_cycler = rcParams['axes.prop_cycle'] 

171 else: 

172 prop_cycler = cycler(*args, **kwargs) 

173 

174 self.prop_cycler = itertools.cycle(prop_cycler) 

175 # This should make a copy 

176 self._prop_keys = prop_cycler.keys 

177 

178 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

179 if self.axes.xaxis is not None and self.axes.yaxis is not None: 

180 xunits = kwargs.pop('xunits', self.axes.xaxis.units) 

181 

182 if self.axes.name == 'polar': 

183 xunits = kwargs.pop('thetaunits', xunits) 

184 

185 yunits = kwargs.pop('yunits', self.axes.yaxis.units) 

186 

187 if self.axes.name == 'polar': 

188 yunits = kwargs.pop('runits', yunits) 

189 

190 if xunits != self.axes.xaxis.units: 

191 self.axes.xaxis.set_units(xunits) 

192 

193 if yunits != self.axes.yaxis.units: 

194 self.axes.yaxis.set_units(yunits) 

195 

196 ret = self._grab_next_args(*args, **kwargs) 

197 return ret 

198 

199 def get_next_color(self): 

200 """Return the next color in the cycle.""" 

201 if 'color' not in self._prop_keys: 

202 return 'k' 

203 return next(self.prop_cycler)['color'] 

204 

205 def set_lineprops(self, line, **kwargs): 

206 assert self.command == 'plot', 'set_lineprops only works with "plot"' 

207 line.set(**kwargs) 

208 

209 def set_patchprops(self, fill_poly, **kwargs): 

210 assert self.command == 'fill', 'set_patchprops only works with "fill"' 

211 fill_poly.set(**kwargs) 

212 

213 def _xy_from_xy(self, x, y): 

214 if self.axes.xaxis is not None and self.axes.yaxis is not None: 

215 bx = self.axes.xaxis.update_units(x) 

216 by = self.axes.yaxis.update_units(y) 

217 

218 if self.command != 'plot': 

219 # the Line2D class can handle unitized data, with 

220 # support for post hoc unit changes etc. Other mpl 

221 # artists, e.g., Polygon which _process_plot_var_args 

222 # also serves on calls to fill, cannot. So this is a 

223 # hack to say: if you are not "plot", which is 

224 # creating Line2D, then convert the data now to 

225 # floats. If you are plot, pass the raw data through 

226 # to Line2D which will handle the conversion. So 

227 # polygons will not support post hoc conversions of 

228 # the unit type since they are not storing the orig 

229 # data. Hopefully we can rationalize this at a later 

230 # date - JDH 

231 if bx: 

232 x = self.axes.convert_xunits(x) 

233 if by: 

234 y = self.axes.convert_yunits(y) 

235 

236 # like asanyarray, but converts scalar to array, and doesn't change 

237 # existing compatible sequences 

238 x = _check_1d(x) 

239 y = _check_1d(y) 

240 if x.shape[0] != y.shape[0]: 

241 raise ValueError("x and y must have same first dimension, but " 

242 "have shapes {} and {}".format(x.shape, y.shape)) 

243 if x.ndim > 2 or y.ndim > 2: 

244 raise ValueError("x and y can be no greater than 2-D, but have " 

245 "shapes {} and {}".format(x.shape, y.shape)) 

246 

247 if x.ndim == 1: 

248 x = x[:, np.newaxis] 

249 if y.ndim == 1: 

250 y = y[:, np.newaxis] 

251 return x, y 

252 

253 def _getdefaults(self, ignore, *kwargs): 

254 """ 

255 Only advance the cycler if the cycler has information that 

256 is not specified in any of the supplied tuple of dicts. 

257 Ignore any keys specified in the `ignore` set. 

258 

259 Returns a copy of defaults dictionary if there are any 

260 keys that are not found in any of the supplied dictionaries. 

261 If the supplied dictionaries have non-None values for 

262 everything the property cycler has, then just return 

263 an empty dictionary. Ignored keys are excluded from the 

264 returned dictionary. 

265 

266 """ 

267 prop_keys = self._prop_keys 

268 if ignore is None: 

269 ignore = set() 

270 prop_keys = prop_keys - ignore 

271 

272 if any(all(kw.get(k, None) is None for kw in kwargs) 

273 for k in prop_keys): 

274 # Need to copy this dictionary or else the next time around 

275 # in the cycle, the dictionary could be missing entries. 

276 default_dict = next(self.prop_cycler).copy() 

277 for p in ignore: 

278 default_dict.pop(p, None) 

279 else: 

280 default_dict = {} 

281 return default_dict 

282 

283 def _setdefaults(self, defaults, *kwargs): 

284 """ 

285 Given a defaults dictionary, and any other dictionaries, 

286 update those other dictionaries with information in defaults if 

287 none of the other dictionaries contains that information. 

288 

289 """ 

290 for k in defaults: 

291 if all(kw.get(k, None) is None for kw in kwargs): 

292 for kw in kwargs: 

293 kw[k] = defaults[k] 

294 

295 def _makeline(self, x, y, kw, kwargs): 

296 kw = kw.copy() # Don't modify the original kw. 

297 kw.update(kwargs) 

298 default_dict = self._getdefaults(None, kw) 

299 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kw) 

300 seg = mlines.Line2D(x, y, **kw) 

301 return seg 

302 

303 def _makefill(self, x, y, kw, kwargs): 

304 kw = kw.copy() # Don't modify the original kw. 

305 kwargs = kwargs.copy() 

306 

307 # Ignore 'marker'-related properties as they aren't Polygon 

308 # properties, but they are Line2D properties, and so they are 

309 # likely to appear in the default cycler construction. 

310 # This is done here to the defaults dictionary as opposed to the 

311 # other two dictionaries because we do want to capture when a 

312 # *user* explicitly specifies a marker which should be an error. 

313 # We also want to prevent advancing the cycler if there are no 

314 # defaults needed after ignoring the given properties. 

315 ignores = {'marker', 'markersize', 'markeredgecolor', 

316 'markerfacecolor', 'markeredgewidth'} 

317 # Also ignore anything provided by *kwargs*. 

318 for k, v in six.iteritems(kwargs): 

319 if v is not None: 

320 ignores.add(k) 

321 

322 # Only using the first dictionary to use as basis 

323 # for getting defaults for back-compat reasons. 

324 # Doing it with both seems to mess things up in 

325 # various places (probably due to logic bugs elsewhere). 

326 default_dict = self._getdefaults(ignores, kw) 

327 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kw) 

328 

329 # Looks like we don't want "color" to be interpreted to 

330 # mean both facecolor and edgecolor for some reason. 

331 # So the "kw" dictionary is thrown out, and only its 

332 # 'color' value is kept and translated as a 'facecolor'. 

333 # This design should probably be revisited as it increases 

334 # complexity. 

335 facecolor = kw.get('color', None) 

336 

337 # Throw out 'color' as it is now handled as a facecolor 

338 default_dict.pop('color', None) 

339 

340 # To get other properties set from the cycler 

341 # modify the kwargs dictionary. 

342 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kwargs) 

343 

344 seg = mpatches.Polygon(np.hstack((x[:, np.newaxis], 

345 y[:, np.newaxis])), 

346 facecolor=facecolor, 

347 fill=kwargs.get('fill', True), 

348 closed=kw['closed']) 

349 self.set_patchprops(seg, **kwargs) 

350 return seg 

351 

352 def _plot_args(self, tup, kwargs): 

353 ret = [] 

354 if len(tup) > 1 and isinstance(tup[-1], six.string_types): 

355 linestyle, marker, color = _process_plot_format(tup[-1]) 

356 tup = tup[:-1] 

357 elif len(tup) == 3: 

358 raise ValueError('third arg must be a format string') 

359 else: 

360 linestyle, marker, color = None, None, None 

361 

362 # Don't allow any None value; These will be up-converted 

363 # to one element array of None which causes problems 

364 # downstream. 

365 if any(v is None for v in tup): 

366 raise ValueError("x and y must not be None") 

367 

368 kw = {} 

369 for k, v in zip(('linestyle', 'marker', 'color'), 

370 (linestyle, marker, color)): 

371 if v is not None: 

372 kw[k] = v 

373 

374 if 'label' not in kwargs or kwargs['label'] is None: 

375 kwargs['label'] = get_label(tup[-1], None) 

376 

377 if len(tup) == 2: 

378 x = _check_1d(tup[0]) 

379 y = _check_1d(tup[-1]) 

380 else: 

381 x, y = index_of(tup[-1]) 

382 

383 x, y = self._xy_from_xy(x, y) 

384 

385 if self.command == 'plot': 

386 func = self._makeline 

387 else: 

388 kw['closed'] = kwargs.get('closed', True) 

389 func = self._makefill 

390 

391 ncx, ncy = x.shape[1], y.shape[1] 

392 if ncx > 1 and ncy > 1 and ncx != ncy: 

393 cbook.warn_deprecated("2.2", "cycling among columns of inputs " 

394 "with non-matching shapes is deprecated.") 

395 for j in xrange(max(ncx, ncy)): 

396 seg = func(x[:, j % ncx], y[:, j % ncy], kw, kwargs) 

397 ret.append(seg) 

398 return ret 

399 

400 def _grab_next_args(self, *args, **kwargs): 

401 while args: 

402 this, args = args[:2], args[2:] 

403 if args and isinstance(args[0], six.string_types): 

404 this += args[0], 

405 args = args[1:] 

406 for seg in self._plot_args(this, kwargs): 

407 yield seg

410class _AxesBase(martist.Artist): 

411 """ 

412 """ 

413 name = "rectilinear" 

414 

415 _shared_x_axes = cbook.Grouper() 

416 _shared_y_axes = cbook.Grouper() 

417 _twinned_axes = cbook.Grouper()

419 def __str__(self): 

420 return "{0}({1[0]:g},{1[1]:g};{1[2]:g}x{1[3]:g})".format( 

421 type(self).__name__, self._position.bounds) 

422 

423 @docstring.Substitution(scale=' | '.join( 

424 [repr(x) for x in mscale.get_scale_names()])) 

425 def __init__(self, fig, rect, 

426 facecolor=None, # defaults to rc axes.facecolor 

427 frameon=True, 

428 sharex=None, # use Axes instance's xaxis info 

429 sharey=None, # use Axes instance's yaxis info 

430 label='', 

431 xscale=None, 

432 yscale=None, 

433 **kwargs 

434 ): 

435 """ 

436 Build an `~axes.Axes` instance in 

437 `~matplotlib.figure.Figure` *fig* with 

438 *rect=[left, bottom, width, height]* in 

439 `~matplotlib.figure.Figure` coordinates 

440 

441 Optional keyword arguments: 

442 

443 ================ ========================================= 

444 Keyword Description 

445 ================ ========================================= 

446 *adjustable* [ 'box' | 'datalim' ] 

447 *alpha* float: the alpha transparency (can be None) 

448 *anchor* [ 'C', 'SW', 'S', 'SE', 'E', 'NE', 'N', 

449 'NW', 'W' ] 

450 *aspect* [ 'auto' | 'equal' | aspect_ratio ] 

451 *autoscale_on* bool; whether to autoscale the *viewlim* 

452 *axisbelow* [ bool | 'line' ] draw the grids 

453 and ticks below or above most other artists, 

454 or below lines but above patches 

455 *cursor_props* a (*float*, *color*) tuple 

456 *figure* a :class:`~matplotlib.figure.Figure` 

457 instance 

458 *frame_on* bool; whether to draw the axes frame 

459 *label* the axes label 

460 *navigate* bool 

461 *navigate_mode* [ 'PAN' | 'ZOOM' | None ] the navigation 

462 toolbar button status 

463 *position* [left, bottom, width, height] in 

464 class:`~matplotlib.figure.Figure` coords 

465 *sharex* an class:`~matplotlib.axes.Axes` instance 

466 to share the x-axis with 

467 *sharey* an class:`~matplotlib.axes.Axes` instance 

468 to share the y-axis with 

469 *title* the title string 

470 *visible* bool, whether the axes is visible 

471 *xlabel* the xlabel 

472 *xlim* (*xmin*, *xmax*) view limits 

473 *xscale* [%(scale)s] 

474 *xticklabels* sequence of strings 

475 *xticks* sequence of floats 

476 *ylabel* the ylabel strings 

477 *ylim* (*ymin*, *ymax*) view limits 

478 *yscale* [%(scale)s] 

479 *yticklabels* sequence of strings 

480 *yticks* sequence of floats 

481 ================ ========================================= 

482 """ 

483 

484 martist.Artist.__init__(self) 

485 if isinstance(rect, mtransforms.Bbox): 

486 self._position = rect 

487 else: 

488 self._position = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*rect) 

489 if self._position.width < 0 or self._position.height < 0: 

490 raise ValueError('Width and height specified must be non-negative')

492 # self.set_axes(self)

501 if sharey is not None:

540 if len(kwargs): 

541 self.update(kwargs) 

542 

543 if self.xaxis is not None:

545 'units finalize', lambda: self._on_units_changed(scalex=True)) 

546 

547 if self.yaxis is not None: 

548 self._ycid = self.yaxis.callbacks.connect( 

549 'units finalize', lambda: self._on_units_changed(scaley=True)) 

550 

551 self.tick_params( 

552 top=rcParams['xtick.top'] and rcParams['xtick.minor.top'], 

553 bottom=rcParams['xtick.bottom'] and rcParams['xtick.minor.bottom'], 

554 labeltop=(rcParams['xtick.labeltop'] and 

555 rcParams['xtick.minor.top']), 

556 labelbottom=(rcParams['xtick.labelbottom'] and 

557 rcParams['xtick.minor.bottom']),

584 def __getstate__(self): 

585 # The renderer should be re-created by the figure, and then cached at 

586 # that point. 

587 state = super(_AxesBase, self).__getstate__() 

588 state['_cachedRenderer'] = None 

589 state.pop('_layoutbox') 

590 state.pop('_poslayoutbox') 

591 

592 return state

594 def __setstate__(self, state): 

595 self.__dict__ = state 

596 # put the _remove_method back on all artists contained within the axes 

597 for container_name in ['lines', 'collections', 'tables', 'patches', 

598 'texts', 'images']: 

599 container = getattr(self, container_name) 

600 for artist in container: 

601 artist._remove_method = container.remove 

602 self._stale = True 

603 self._layoutbox = None 

604 self._poslayoutbox = None

606 def get_window_extent(self, *args, **kwargs): 

607 """ 

608 get the axes bounding box in display space; *args* and 

609 *kwargs* are empty 

610 """ 

611 bbox = self.bbox 

612 x_pad = self.xaxis.get_tick_padding() 

613 y_pad = self.yaxis.get_tick_padding() 

614 return mtransforms.Bbox([[bbox.x0 - x_pad, bbox.y0 - y_pad], 

615 [bbox.x1 + x_pad, bbox.y1 + y_pad]])

617 def _init_axis(self): 

618 "move this out of __init__ because non-separable axes don't use it" 

619 self.xaxis = maxis.XAxis(self) 

620 self.spines['bottom'].register_axis(self.xaxis) 

621 self.spines['top'].register_axis(self.xaxis) 

622 self.yaxis = maxis.YAxis(self) 

623 self.spines['left'].register_axis(self.yaxis) 

624 self.spines['right'].register_axis(self.yaxis) 

625 self._update_transScale()

627 def set_figure(self, fig): 

628 """ 

629 Set the `.Figure` for this `.Axes`. 

630 

631 .. ACCEPTS: `.Figure` 

632 

633 Parameters 

634 ---------- 

635 fig : `.Figure` 

636 """ 

637 martist.Artist.set_figure(self, fig) 

638 

639 self.bbox = mtransforms.TransformedBbox(self._position, 

640 fig.transFigure) 

641 # these will be updated later as data is added 

642 self.dataLim = mtransforms.Bbox.null() 

643 self.viewLim = mtransforms.Bbox.unit() 

644 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper( 

645 mtransforms.IdentityTransform()) 

646 

647 self._set_lim_and_transforms() 

648 

649 def _set_lim_and_transforms(self): 

650 """ 

651 set the *_xaxis_transform*, *_yaxis_transform*, 

652 *transScale*, *transData*, *transLimits* and *transAxes* 

653 transformations. 

654 

655 .. note:: 

656 

657 This method is primarily used by rectilinear projections 

658 of the :class:`~matplotlib.axes.Axes` class, and is meant 

659 to be overridden by new kinds of projection axes that need 

660 different transformations and limits. (See 

661 :class:`~matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes` for an 

662 example. 

663 

664 """ 

665 self.transAxes = mtransforms.BboxTransformTo(self.bbox) 

666 

667 # Transforms the x and y axis separately by a scale factor. 

668 # It is assumed that this part will have non-linear components 

669 # (e.g., for a log scale). 

670 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper( 

671 mtransforms.IdentityTransform()) 

672 

673 # An affine transformation on the data, generally to limit the 

674 # range of the axes 

675 self.transLimits = mtransforms.BboxTransformFrom( 

676 mtransforms.TransformedBbox(self.viewLim, self.transScale)) 

677 

678 # The parentheses are important for efficiency here -- they 

679 # group the last two (which are usually affines) separately 

680 # from the first (which, with log-scaling can be non-affine). 

681 self.transData = self.transScale + (self.transLimits + self.transAxes) 

682 

683 self._xaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

684 self.transData, self.transAxes) 

685 self._yaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

686 self.transAxes, self.transData) 

687 

688 def get_xaxis_transform(self, which='grid'): 

689 """ 

690 Get the transformation used for drawing x-axis labels, ticks 

691 and gridlines. The x-direction is in data coordinates and the 

692 y-direction is in axis coordinates. 

693 

694 .. note:: 

695 

696 This transformation is primarily used by the 

697 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

698 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

699 place axis elements in different locations. 

700 

701 """ 

702 if which == 'grid': 

703 return self._xaxis_transform 

704 elif which == 'tick1': 

705 # for cartesian projection, this is bottom spine 

706 return self.spines['bottom'].get_spine_transform() 

707 elif which == 'tick2': 

708 # for cartesian projection, this is top spine 

709 return self.spines['top'].get_spine_transform() 

710 else: 

711 raise ValueError('unknown value for which') 

712 

713 def get_xaxis_text1_transform(self, pad_points): 

714 """ 

715 Get the transformation used for drawing x-axis labels, which 

716 will add the given amount of padding (in points) between the 

717 axes and the label. The x-direction is in data coordinates 

718 and the y-direction is in axis coordinates. Returns a 

719 3-tuple of the form:: 

720 

721 (transform, valign, halign) 

722 

723 where *valign* and *halign* are requested alignments for the 

724 text. 

725 

726 .. note:: 

727 

728 This transformation is primarily used by the 

729 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

730 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

731 place axis elements in different locations. 

732 

733 """ 

734 labels_align = matplotlib.rcParams["xtick.alignment"] 

735 

736 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick1') + 

737 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(0, -1 * pad_points / 72.0, 

738 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans), 

739 "top", labels_align) 

740 

741 def get_xaxis_text2_transform(self, pad_points): 

742 """ 

743 Get the transformation used for drawing the secondary x-axis 

744 labels, which will add the given amount of padding (in points) 

745 between the axes and the label. The x-direction is in data 

746 coordinates and the y-direction is in axis coordinates. 

747 Returns a 3-tuple of the form:: 

748 

749 (transform, valign, halign) 

750 

751 where *valign* and *halign* are requested alignments for the 

752 text. 

753 

754 .. note:: 

755 

756 This transformation is primarily used by the 

757 :class:`~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be 

758 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to 

759 place axis elements in different locations. 

760 

761 """ 

762 labels_align = matplotlib.rcParams["xtick.alignment"] 

763 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick2') + 

764 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(0, pad_points / 72.0, 

765 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans), 

766 "bottom", labels_align) 

767

790 else:

848 def _update_transScale(self): 

849 self.transScale.set( 

850 mtransforms.blended_transform_factory( 

851 self.xaxis.get_transform(), self.yaxis.get_transform())) 

852 if hasattr(self, "lines"): 

853 for line in self.lines: 

854 try: 

855 line._transformed_path.invalidate() 

856 except AttributeError: 

857 pass

859 def get_position(self, original=False): 

860 """ 

861 Get a copy of the axes rectangle as a `.Bbox`. 

862 

863 Parameters 

864 ---------- 

865 original : bool 

866 If ``True``, return the original position. Otherwise return the 

867 active position. For an explanation of the positions see 

868 `.set_position`. 

869 

870 Returns 

871 ------- 

872 pos : `.Bbox` 

873 

874 """ 

875 if original: 

876 return self._originalPosition.frozen() 

877 else: 

878 return self._position.frozen() 

879 

880 def set_position(self, pos, which='both'): 

881 """ 

882 Set the axes position. 

883 

884 Axes have two position attributes. The 'original' position is the 

885 position allocated for the Axes. The 'active' position is the 

886 position the Axes is actually drawn at. These positions are usually 

887 the same unless a fixed aspect is set to the Axes. See `.set_aspect` 

888 for details. 

889 

890 Parameters 

891 ---------- 

892 pos : [left, bottom, width, height] or `~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox` 

893 The new position of the in `.Figure` coordinates. 

894 

895 which : ['both' | 'active' | 'original'], optional 

896 Determines which position variables to change. 

897 

898 """ 

899 self._set_position(pos, which='both') 

900 # because this is being called externally to the library we 

901 # zero the constrained layout parts. 

902 self._layoutbox = None 

903 self._poslayoutbox = None 

904 

905 def _set_position(self, pos, which='both'): 

906 """ 

907 private version of set_position. Call this internally 

908 to get the same functionality of `get_position`, but not 

909 to take the axis out of the constrained_layout 

910 hierarchy. 

911 """ 

912 if not isinstance(pos, mtransforms.BboxBase): 

913 pos = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*pos) 

914 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self): 

915 if which in ('both', 'active'): 

916 ax._position.set(pos) 

917 if which in ('both', 'original'): 

918 ax._originalPosition.set(pos) 

919 self.stale = True 

920 

921 def reset_position(self): 

922 """ 

923 Reset the active position to the original position. 

924 

925 This resets the a possible position change due to aspect constraints. 

926 For an explanation of the positions see `.set_position`. 

927 """ 

928 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self): 

929 pos = ax.get_position(original=True) 

930 ax.set_position(pos, which='active') 

931

933 """ 

934 Set the axes locator. 

935 

936 .. ACCEPTS: a callable object which takes an axes instance and 

937 renderer and returns a bbox. 

938 

939 Parameters 

940 ---------- 

941 locator : callable 

942 A locator function, which takes an axes and a renderer and returns 

943 a bbox. 

944 """ 

945 self._axes_locator = locator 

946 self.stale = True 

947 

948 def get_axes_locator(self): 

949 """ 

950 Return the axes_locator. 

951 """ 

952 return self._axes_locator

954 def _set_artist_props(self, a): 

955 """set the boilerplate props for artists added to axes""" 

956 a.set_figure(self.figure) 

957 if not a.is_transform_set(): 

958 a.set_transform(self.transData) 

959 

960 a.axes = self 

961 if a.mouseover: 

962 self.mouseover_set.add(a) 

963 

964 def _gen_axes_patch(self): 

965 """ 

966 Returns the patch used to draw the background of the axes. It 

967 is also used as the clipping path for any data elements on the 

968 axes. 

969 

970 In the standard axes, this is a rectangle, but in other 

971 projections it may not be. 

972 

973 .. note:: 

974 

975 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

976 

977 """ 

978 return mpatches.Rectangle((0.0, 0.0), 1.0, 1.0) 

979 

980 def _gen_axes_spines(self, locations=None, offset=0.0, units='inches'): 

981 """ 

982 Returns a dict whose keys are spine names and values are 

983 Line2D or Patch instances. Each element is used to draw a 

984 spine of the axes. 

985 

986 In the standard axes, this is a single line segment, but in 

987 other projections it may not be. 

988 

989 .. note:: 

990 

991 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

992 

993 """ 

994 return OrderedDict([ 

995 ('left', mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, 'left')), 

996 ('right', mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, 'right')), 

997 ('bottom', mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, 'bottom')), 

998 ('top', mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, 'top'))]) 

999 

1000 def cla(self): 

1001 """Clear the current axes.""" 

1002 # Note: this is called by Axes.__init__() 

1003 

1004 # stash the current visibility state 

1005 if hasattr(self, 'patch'): 

1006 patch_visible = self.patch.get_visible() 

1007 else: 

1008 patch_visible = True 

1009 

1010 xaxis_visible = self.xaxis.get_visible() 

1011 yaxis_visible = self.yaxis.get_visible() 

1012 

1013 self.xaxis.cla() 

1014 self.yaxis.cla() 

1015 

1016 for name, spine in six.iteritems(self.spines): 

1017 spine.cla() 

1018 

1019 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = True 

1020 self.callbacks = cbook.CallbackRegistry() 

1021 

1022 if self._sharex is not None: 

1023 # major and minor are axis.Ticker class instances with 

1024 # locator and formatter attributes 

1025 self.xaxis.major = self._sharex.xaxis.major 

1026 self.xaxis.minor = self._sharex.xaxis.minor 

1027 x0, x1 = self._sharex.get_xlim() 

1028 self.set_xlim(x0, x1, emit=False, auto=None) 

1029 self.xaxis._scale = mscale.scale_factory( 

1030 self._sharex.xaxis.get_scale(), self.xaxis) 

1031 else: 

1032 self.xaxis._set_scale('linear') 

1033 try: 

1034 self.set_xlim(0, 1) 

1035 except TypeError: 

1036 pass 

1037 

1038 if self._sharey is not None: 

1039 self.yaxis.major = self._sharey.yaxis.major 

1040 self.yaxis.minor = self._sharey.yaxis.minor 

1041 y0, y1 = self._sharey.get_ylim() 

1042 self.set_ylim(y0, y1, emit=False, auto=None) 

1043 self.yaxis._scale = mscale.scale_factory( 

1044 self._sharey.yaxis.get_scale(), self.yaxis) 

1045 else: 

1046 self.yaxis._set_scale('linear') 

1047 try: 

1048 self.set_ylim(0, 1) 

1049 except TypeError: 

1050 pass 

1051 # update the minor locator for x and y axis based on rcParams 

1052 if (rcParams['xtick.minor.visible']): 

1053 self.xaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

1054 

1055 if (rcParams['ytick.minor.visible']): 

1056 self.yaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

1057 

1058 self._autoscaleXon = True 

1059 self._autoscaleYon = True 

1060 self._xmargin = rcParams['axes.xmargin'] 

1061 self._ymargin = rcParams['axes.ymargin'] 

1062 self._tight = None 

1063 self._use_sticky_edges = True 

1064 self._update_transScale() # needed? 

1065 

1066 self._get_lines = _process_plot_var_args(self) 

1067 self._get_patches_for_fill = _process_plot_var_args(self, 'fill') 

1068 

1069 self._gridOn = rcParams['axes.grid'] 

1070 self.lines = [] 

1071 self.patches = [] 

1072 self.texts = [] 

1073 self.tables = [] 

1074 self.artists = [] 

1075 self.images = [] 

1076 self.mouseover_set = set() 

1077 self._current_image = None # strictly for pyplot via _sci, _gci 

1078 self.legend_ = None 

1079 self.collections = [] # collection.Collection instances 

1080 self.containers = [] 

1081 

1082 self.grid(False) # Disable grid on init to use rcParameter 

1083 self.grid(self._gridOn, which=rcParams['axes.grid.which'], 

1084 axis=rcParams['axes.grid.axis']) 

1085 props = font_manager.FontProperties( 

1086 size=rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

1087 weight=rcParams['axes.titleweight']) 

1088 

1089 self.title = mtext.Text( 

1090 x=0.5, y=1.0, text='', 

1091 fontproperties=props, 

1092 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1093 horizontalalignment='center', 

1094 ) 

1095 self._left_title = mtext.Text( 

1096 x=0.0, y=1.0, text='', 

1097 fontproperties=props.copy(), 

1098 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1099 horizontalalignment='left', ) 

1100 self._right_title = mtext.Text( 

1101 x=1.0, y=1.0, text='', 

1102 fontproperties=props.copy(), 

1103 verticalalignment='baseline', 

1104 horizontalalignment='right', 

1105 ) 

1106 title_offset_points = rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

1107 # refactor this out so it can be called in ax.set_title if 

1108 # pad argument used... 

1109 self._set_title_offset_trans(title_offset_points) 

1110 

1111 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title): 

1112 self._set_artist_props(_title) 

1113 

1114 # The patch draws the background of the axes. We want this to be below 

1115 # the other artists. We use the frame to draw the edges so we are 

1116 # setting the edgecolor to None. 

1117 self.patch = self._gen_axes_patch() 

1118 self.patch.set_figure(self.figure) 

1119 self.patch.set_facecolor(self._facecolor) 

1120 self.patch.set_edgecolor('None') 

1121 self.patch.set_linewidth(0) 

1122 self.patch.set_transform(self.transAxes) 

1123 

1124 self.set_axis_on() 

1125 

1126 self.xaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1127 self.yaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1128 

1129 self._shared_x_axes.clean() 

1130 self._shared_y_axes.clean() 

1131 if self._sharex: 

1132 self.xaxis.set_visible(xaxis_visible) 

1133 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible) 

1134 

1135 if self._sharey: 

1136 self.yaxis.set_visible(yaxis_visible) 

1137 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible) 

1138 

1139 self.stale = True 

1140 

1141 @property 

1142 @cbook.deprecated("2.1", alternative="Axes.patch") 

1143 def axesPatch(self): 

1144 return self.patch 

1145 

1146 def clear(self): 

1147 """Clear the axes.""" 

1148 self.cla() 

1149 

1150 def get_facecolor(self): 

1151 """Get the Axes facecolor.""" 

1152 return self.patch.get_facecolor() 

1153 get_fc = get_facecolor 

1154 

1155 def set_facecolor(self, color): 

1156 """Set the Axes facecolor. 

1157 

1158 .. ACCEPTS: color 

1159 

1160 Parameters 

1161 ---------- 

1162 color : color 

1163 """ 

1164 self._facecolor = color 

1165 self.stale = True 

1166 return self.patch.set_facecolor(color) 

1167 set_fc = set_facecolor

1169 def _set_title_offset_trans(self, title_offset_points): 

1170 """ 

1171 Set the offset for the title either from rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

1172 or from set_title kwarg ``pad``. 

1173 """ 

1174 self.titleOffsetTrans = mtransforms.ScaledTranslation( 

1175 0.0, title_offset_points / 72.0, 

1176 self.figure.dpi_scale_trans) 

1177 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title): 

1178 _title.set_transform(self.transAxes + self.titleOffsetTrans) 

1179 _title.set_clip_box(None) 

1180 

1181 def set_prop_cycle(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1182 """ 

1183 Set the property cycle of the Axes. 

1184 

1185 The property cycle controls the style properties such as color, 

1186 marker and linestyle of future plot commands. The style properties 

1187 of data already added to the Axes are not modified. 

1188 

1189 Call signatures:: 

1190 

1191 set_prop_cycle(cycler) 

1192 set_prop_cycle(label=values[, label2=values2[, ...]]) 

1193 set_prop_cycle(label, values) 

1194 

1195 Form 1 sets given `~cycler.Cycler` object. 

1196 

1197 Form 2 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` which cycles over one or more 

1198 properties simultaneously and set it as the property cycle of the 

1199 axes. If multiple properties are given, their value lists must have 

1200 the same length. This is just a shortcut for explicitly creating a 

1201 cycler and passing it to the function, i.e. it's short for 

1202 ``set_prop_cycle(cycler(label=values label2=values2, ...))``. 

1203 

1204 Form 3 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` for a single property and set it 

1205 as the property cycle of the axes. This form exists for compatibility 

1206 with the original `cycler.cycler` interface. Its use is discouraged 

1207 in favor of the kwarg form, i.e. ``set_prop_cycle(label=values)``. 

1208 

1209 Parameters 

1210 ---------- 

1211 cycler : Cycler 

1212 Set the given Cycler. *None* resets to the cycle defined by the 

1213 current style. 

1214 

1215 label : str 

1216 The property key. Must be a valid `.Artist` property. 

1217 For example, 'color' or 'linestyle'. Aliases are allowed, 

1218 such as 'c' for 'color' and 'lw' for 'linewidth'. 

1219 

1220 values : iterable 

1221 Finite-length iterable of the property values. These values 

1222 are validated and will raise a ValueError if invalid. 

1223 

1224 Examples 

1225 -------- 

1226 Setting the property cycle for a single property: 

1227 

1228 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue']) 

1229 

1230 Setting the property cycle for simultaneously cycling over multiple 

1231 properties (e.g. red circle, green plus, blue cross): 

1232 

1233 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue'], 

1234 ... marker=['o', '+', 'x']) 

1235 

1236 See Also 

1237 -------- 

1238 matplotlib.rcsetup.cycler 

1239 Convenience function for creating validated cyclers for properties. 

1240 cycler.cycler 

1241 The original function for creating unvalidated cyclers. 

1242 

1243 """ 

1244 if args and kwargs: 

1245 raise TypeError("Cannot supply both positional and keyword " 

1246 "arguments to this method.") 

1247 if len(args) == 1 and args[0] is None: 

1248 prop_cycle = None 

1249 else: 

1250 prop_cycle = cycler(*args, **kwargs) 

1251 self._get_lines.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle) 

1252 self._get_patches_for_fill.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle) 

1253 

1254 @cbook.deprecated('1.5', alternative='`.set_prop_cycle`') 

1255 def set_color_cycle(self, clist): 

1256 """ 

1257 Set the color cycle for any future plot commands on this Axes. 

1258 

1259 Parameters 

1260 ---------- 

1261 clist 

1262 A list of mpl color specifiers. 

1263 """ 

1264 if clist is None: 

1265 # Calling set_color_cycle() or set_prop_cycle() with None 

1266 # effectively resets the cycle, but you can't do 

1267 # set_prop_cycle('color', None). So we are special-casing this. 

1268 self.set_prop_cycle(None) 

1269 else: 

1270 self.set_prop_cycle('color', clist) 

1271 

1272 @cbook.deprecated("2.0") 

1273 def ishold(self): 

1274 """return the HOLD status of the axes 

1275 

1276 The `hold` mechanism is deprecated and will be removed in 

1277 v3.0. 

1278 """ 

1279 

1280 return self._hold 

1281 

1282 @cbook.deprecated("2.0", message=_hold_msg) 

1283 def hold(self, b=None): 

1284 """ 

1285 Set the hold state. 

1286 

1287 The ``hold`` mechanism is deprecated and will be removed in 

1288 v3.0. The behavior will remain consistent with the 

1289 long-time default value of True. 

1290 

1291 If *hold* is *None* (default), toggle the *hold* state. Else 

1292 set the *hold* state to boolean value *b*. 

1293 

1294 Examples:: 

1295 

1296 # toggle hold 

1297 hold() 

1298 

1299 # turn hold on 

1300 hold(True) 

1301 

1302 # turn hold off 

1303 hold(False) 

1304 

1305 When hold is *True*, subsequent plot commands will be added to 

1306 the current axes. When hold is *False*, the current axes and 

1307 figure will be cleared on the next plot command 

1308 

1309 """ 

1310 if b is None: 

1311 self._hold = not self._hold 

1312 else: 

1313 self._hold = b 

1314 

1315 def get_aspect(self): 

1316 return self._aspect 

1317 

1318 def set_aspect(self, aspect, adjustable=None, anchor=None, share=False): 

1319 """ 

1320 Set the aspect of the axis scaling, i.e. the ratio of y-unit to x-unit. 

1321 

1322 Parameters 

1323 ---------- 

1324 aspect : ['auto' | 'equal'] or num 

1325 Possible values: 

1326 

1327 ======== ================================================ 

1328 value description 

1329 ======== ================================================ 

1330 'auto' automatic; fill the position rectangle with data 

1331 'equal' same scaling from data to plot units for x and y 

1332 num a circle will be stretched such that the height 

1333 is num times the width. aspect=1 is the same as 

1334 aspect='equal'. 

1335 ======== ================================================ 

1336 

1337 adjustable : None or ['box' | 'datalim'], optional 

1338 If not ``None``, this defines which parameter will be adjusted to 

1339 meet the required aspect. See `.set_adjustable` for further 

1340 details. 

1341 

1342 anchor : None or str or 2-tuple of float, optional 

1343 If not ``None``, this defines where the Axes will be drawn if there 

1344 is extra space due to aspect constraints. The most common way to 

1345 to specify the anchor are abbreviations of cardinal directions: 

1346 

1347 ===== ===================== 

1348 value description 

1349 ===== ===================== 

1350 'C' centered 

1351 'SW' lower left corner 

1352 'S' middle of bottom edge 

1353 'SE' lower right corner 

1354 etc. 

1355 ===== ===================== 

1356 

1357 See `.set_anchor` for further details. 

1358 

1359 share : bool, optional 

1360 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1361 Default is ``False``. 

1362 

1363 See Also 

1364 -------- 

1365 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable 

1366 defining the parameter to adjust in order to meet the required 

1367 aspect. 

1368 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1369 defining the position in case of extra space. 

1370 """ 

1371 if not (isinstance(aspect, six.string_types) 

1372 and aspect in ('equal', 'auto')): 

1373 aspect = float(aspect) # raise ValueError if necessary 

1374 if share: 

1375 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1376 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1377 else: 

1378 axes = [self] 

1379 for ax in axes: 

1380 ax._aspect = aspect 

1381 

1382 if adjustable is None: 

1383 adjustable = self._adjustable 

1384 self.set_adjustable(adjustable, share=share) # Handle sharing. 

1385 

1386 if anchor is not None: 

1387 self.set_anchor(anchor, share=share) 

1388 self.stale = True 

1389 

1390 def get_adjustable(self): 

1391 return self._adjustable 

1392 

1393 def set_adjustable(self, adjustable, share=False): 

1394 """ 

1395 Define which parameter the Axes will change to achieve a given aspect. 

1396 

1397 Parameters 

1398 ---------- 

1399 adjustable : ['box' | 'datalim'] 

1400 If 'box', change the physical dimensions of the Axes. 

1401 If 'datalim', change the ``x`` or ``y`` data limits. 

1402 

1403 share : bool, optional 

1404 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1405 Default is ``False``. 

1406 

1407 .. ACCEPTS: [ 'box' | 'datalim'] 

1408 

1409 See Also 

1410 -------- 

1411 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1412 for a description of aspect handling. 

1413 

1414 Notes 

1415 ----- 

1416 Shared Axes (of which twinned Axes are a special case) 

1417 impose restrictions on how aspect ratios can be imposed. 

1418 For twinned Axes, use 'datalim'. For Axes that share both 

1419 x and y, use 'box'. Otherwise, either 'datalim' or 'box' 

1420 may be used. These limitations are partly a requirement 

1421 to avoid over-specification, and partly a result of the 

1422 particular implementation we are currently using, in 

1423 which the adjustments for aspect ratios are done sequentially 

1424 and independently on each Axes as it is drawn. 

1425 """ 

1426 if adjustable == 'box-forced': 

1427 warnings.warn("The 'box-forced' keyword argument is deprecated" 

1428 " since 2.2.", cbook.mplDeprecation) 

1429 if adjustable not in ('box', 'datalim', 'box-forced'): 

1430 raise ValueError("argument must be 'box', or 'datalim'") 

1431 if share: 

1432 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1433 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1434 else: 

1435 axes = [self] 

1436 for ax in axes: 

1437 ax._adjustable = adjustable 

1438 self.stale = True 

1439 

1440 def get_anchor(self): 

1441 """ 

1442 Get the anchor location. 

1443 

1444 See Also 

1445 -------- 

1446 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1447 for a description of the anchor. 

1448 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1449 for a description of aspect handling. 

1450 """ 

1451 return self._anchor 

1452 

1453 def set_anchor(self, anchor, share=False): 

1454 """ 

1455 Define the anchor location. 

1456 

1457 The actual drawing area (active position) of the Axes may be smaller 

1458 than the Bbox (original position) when a fixed aspect is required. The 

1459 anchor defines where the drawing area will be located within the 

1460 available space. 

1461 

1462 .. ACCEPTS: [ 'C' | 'SW' | 'S' | 'SE' | 'E' | 'NE' | 'N' | 'NW' | 'W' ] 

1463 

1464 Parameters 

1465 ---------- 

1466 anchor : str or 2-tuple of floats 

1467 The anchor position may be either: 

1468 

1469 - a sequence (*cx*, *cy*). *cx* and *cy* may range from 0 

1470 to 1, where 0 is left or bottom and 1 is right or top. 

1471 

1472 - a string using cardinal directions as abbreviation: 

1473 

1474 - 'C' for centered 

1475 - 'S' (south) for bottom-center 

1476 - 'SW' (south west) for bottom-left 

1477 - etc. 

1478 

1479 Here is an overview of the possible positions: 

1480 

1481 +------+------+------+ 

1482 | 'NW' | 'N' | 'NE' | 

1483 +------+------+------+ 

1484 | 'W' | 'C' | 'E' | 

1485 +------+------+------+ 

1486 | 'SW' | 'S' | 'SE' | 

1487 +------+------+------+ 

1488 

1489 share : bool, optional 

1490 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes. 

1491 Default is ``False``. 

1492 

1493 See Also 

1494 -------- 

1495 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1496 for a description of aspect handling. 

1497 """ 

1498 if not (anchor in mtransforms.Bbox.coefs or len(anchor) == 2): 

1499 raise ValueError('argument must be among %s' % 

1500 ', '.join(mtransforms.Bbox.coefs)) 

1501 if share: 

1502 axes = set(self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self) 

1503 + self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self)) 

1504 else: 

1505 axes = [self] 

1506 for ax in axes: 

1507 ax._anchor = anchor 

1508 

1509 self.stale = True 

1510 

1511 def get_data_ratio(self): 

1512 """ 

1513 Returns the aspect ratio of the raw data. 

1514 

1515 This method is intended to be overridden by new projection 

1516 types. 

1517 """ 

1518 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1519 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1520 

1521 xsize = max(abs(xmax - xmin), 1e-30) 

1522 ysize = max(abs(ymax - ymin), 1e-30) 

1523 

1524 return ysize / xsize 

1525 

1526 def get_data_ratio_log(self): 

1527 """ 

1528 Returns the aspect ratio of the raw data in log scale. 

1529 Will be used when both axis scales are in log. 

1530 """ 

1531 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1532 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1533 

1534 xsize = max(abs(math.log10(xmax) - math.log10(xmin)), 1e-30) 

1535 ysize = max(abs(math.log10(ymax) - math.log10(ymin)), 1e-30) 

1536 

1537 return ysize / xsize 

1538 

1539 def apply_aspect(self, position=None): 

1540 """ 

1541 Adjust the Axes for a specified data aspect ratio. 

1542 

1543 Depending on `.get_adjustable` this will modify either the Axes box 

1544 (position) or the view limits. In the former case, `.get_anchor` 

1545 will affect the position. 

1546 

1547 Notes 

1548 ----- 

1549 This is called automatically when each Axes is drawn. You may need 

1550 to call it yourself if you need to update the Axes position and/or 

1551 view limits before the Figure is drawn. 

1552 

1553 See Also 

1554 -------- 

1555 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect 

1556 for a description of aspect ratio handling. 

1557 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable 

1558 defining the parameter to adjust in order to meet the required 

1559 aspect. 

1560 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor 

1561 defining the position in case of extra space. 

1562 """ 

1563 if position is None: 

1564 position = self.get_position(original=True) 

1565 

1566 aspect = self.get_aspect() 

1567 

1568 if self.name != 'polar': 

1569 xscale, yscale = self.get_xscale(), self.get_yscale() 

1570 if xscale == "linear" and yscale == "linear": 

1571 aspect_scale_mode = "linear" 

1572 elif xscale == "log" and yscale == "log": 

1573 aspect_scale_mode = "log" 

1574 elif ((xscale == "linear" and yscale == "log") or 

1575 (xscale == "log" and yscale == "linear")): 

1576 if aspect != "auto": 

1577 warnings.warn( 

1578 'aspect is not supported for Axes with xscale=%s, ' 

1579 'yscale=%s' % (xscale, yscale)) 

1580 aspect = "auto" 

1581 else: # some custom projections have their own scales. 

1582 pass 

1583 else: 

1584 aspect_scale_mode = "linear" 

1585 

1586 if aspect == 'auto': 

1587 self._set_position(position, which='active') 

1588 return 

1589 

1590 if aspect == 'equal': 

1591 A = 1 

1592 else: 

1593 A = aspect 

1594 

1595 figW, figH = self.get_figure().get_size_inches() 

1596 fig_aspect = figH / figW 

1597 if self._adjustable in ['box', 'box-forced']: 

1598 if self in self._twinned_axes: 

1599 raise RuntimeError("Adjustable 'box' is not allowed in a" 

1600 " twinned Axes. Use 'datalim' instead.") 

1601 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1602 box_aspect = A * self.get_data_ratio_log() 

1603 else: 

1604 box_aspect = A * self.get_data_ratio() 

1605 pb = position.frozen() 

1606 pb1 = pb.shrunk_to_aspect(box_aspect, pb, fig_aspect) 

1607 self._set_position(pb1.anchored(self.get_anchor(), pb), 'active') 

1608 return 

1609 

1610 # reset active to original in case it had been changed 

1611 # by prior use of 'box' 

1612 self._set_position(position, which='active') 

1613 

1614 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

1615 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

1616 

1617 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1618 xmin, xmax = math.log10(xmin), math.log10(xmax) 

1619 ymin, ymax = math.log10(ymin), math.log10(ymax) 

1620 

1621 xsize = max(abs(xmax - xmin), 1e-30) 

1622 ysize = max(abs(ymax - ymin), 1e-30) 

1623 

1624 l, b, w, h = position.bounds 

1625 box_aspect = fig_aspect * (h / w) 

1626 data_ratio = box_aspect / A 

1627 

1628 y_expander = (data_ratio * xsize / ysize - 1.0) 

1629 # If y_expander > 0, the dy/dx viewLim ratio needs to increase 

1630 if abs(y_expander) < 0.005: 

1631 return 

1632 

1633 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1634 dL = self.dataLim 

1635 dL_width = math.log10(dL.x1) - math.log10(dL.x0) 

1636 dL_height = math.log10(dL.y1) - math.log10(dL.y0) 

1637 xr = 1.05 * dL_width 

1638 yr = 1.05 * dL_height 

1639 else: 

1640 dL = self.dataLim 

1641 xr = 1.05 * dL.width 

1642 yr = 1.05 * dL.height 

1643 

1644 xmarg = xsize - xr 

1645 ymarg = ysize - yr 

1646 Ysize = data_ratio * xsize 

1647 Xsize = ysize / data_ratio 

1648 Xmarg = Xsize - xr 

1649 Ymarg = Ysize - yr 

1650 # Setting these targets to, e.g., 0.05*xr does not seem to 

1651 # help. 

1652 xm = 0 

1653 ym = 0 

1654 

1655 shared_x = self in self._shared_x_axes 

1656 shared_y = self in self._shared_y_axes 

1657 # Not sure whether we need this check: 

1658 if shared_x and shared_y: 

1659 raise RuntimeError("adjustable='datalim' is not allowed when both" 

1660 " axes are shared.") 

1661 

1662 # If y is shared, then we are only allowed to change x, etc. 

1663 if shared_y: 

1664 adjust_y = False 

1665 else: 

1666 if xmarg > xm and ymarg > ym: 

1667 adjy = ((Ymarg > 0 and y_expander < 0) or 

1668 (Xmarg < 0 and y_expander > 0)) 

1669 else: 

1670 adjy = y_expander > 0 

1671 adjust_y = shared_x or adjy # (Ymarg > xmarg) 

1672 

1673 if adjust_y: 

1674 yc = 0.5 * (ymin + ymax) 

1675 y0 = yc - Ysize / 2.0 

1676 y1 = yc + Ysize / 2.0 

1677 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1678 self.set_ybound((10. ** y0, 10. ** y1)) 

1679 else: 

1680 self.set_ybound((y0, y1)) 

1681 else: 

1682 xc = 0.5 * (xmin + xmax) 

1683 x0 = xc - Xsize / 2.0 

1684 x1 = xc + Xsize / 2.0 

1685 if aspect_scale_mode == "log": 

1686 self.set_xbound((10. ** x0, 10. ** x1)) 

1687 else: 

1688 self.set_xbound((x0, x1)) 

1689 

1690 def axis(self, *v, **kwargs): 

1691 """Set axis properties. 

1692 

1693 Valid signatures:: 

1694 

1695 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis() 

1696 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(list_arg) 

1697 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(string_arg) 

1698 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(**kwargs) 

1699 

1700 Parameters 

1701 ---------- 

1702 v : list of float or {'on', 'off', 'equal', 'tight', 'scaled',\ 

1703 'normal', 'auto', 'image', 'square'} 

1704 Optional positional argument 

1705 

1706 Axis data limits set from a list; or a command relating to axes: 

1707 

1708 ========== ================================================ 

1709 Value Description 

1710 ========== ================================================ 

1711 'on' Toggle axis lines and labels on 

1712 'off' Toggle axis lines and labels off 

1713 'equal' Equal scaling by changing limits 

1714 'scaled' Equal scaling by changing box dimensions 

1715 'tight' Limits set such that all data is shown 

1716 'auto' Automatic scaling, fill rectangle with data 

1717 'normal' Same as 'auto'; deprecated 

1718 'image' 'scaled' with axis limits equal to data limits 

1719 'square' Square plot; similar to 'scaled', but initially\ 

1720 forcing xmax-xmin = ymax-ymin 

1721 ========== ================================================ 

1722 

1723 emit : bool, optional 

1724 Passed to set_{x,y}lim functions, if observers 

1725 are notified of axis limit change 

1726 

1727 xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax : float, optional 

1728 The axis limits to be set 

1729 

1730 Returns 

1731 ------- 

1732 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax : float 

1733 The axis limits 

1734 

1735 """ 

1736 

1737 if len(v) == 0 and len(kwargs) == 0: 

1738 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

1739 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

1740 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1741 

1742 emit = kwargs.get('emit', True) 

1743 

1744 if len(v) == 1 and isinstance(v[0], six.string_types): 

1745 s = v[0].lower() 

1746 if s == 'on': 

1747 self.set_axis_on() 

1748 elif s == 'off': 

1749 self.set_axis_off() 

1750 elif s in ('equal', 'tight', 'scaled', 'normal', 

1751 'auto', 'image', 'square'): 

1752 self.set_autoscale_on(True) 

1753 self.set_aspect('auto') 

1754 self.autoscale_view(tight=False) 

1755 # self.apply_aspect() 

1756 if s == 'equal': 

1757 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='datalim') 

1758 elif s == 'scaled': 

1759 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1760 self.set_autoscale_on(False) # Req. by Mark Bakker 

1761 elif s == 'tight': 

1762 self.autoscale_view(tight=True) 

1763 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1764 elif s == 'image': 

1765 self.autoscale_view(tight=True) 

1766 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1767 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1768 elif s == 'square': 

1769 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C') 

1770 self.set_autoscale_on(False) 

1771 xlim = self.get_xlim() 

1772 ylim = self.get_ylim() 

1773 edge_size = max(np.diff(xlim), np.diff(ylim)) 

1774 self.set_xlim([xlim[0], xlim[0] + edge_size], 

1775 emit=emit, auto=False) 

1776 self.set_ylim([ylim[0], ylim[0] + edge_size], 

1777 emit=emit, auto=False) 

1778 else: 

1779 raise ValueError('Unrecognized string %s to axis; ' 

1780 'try on or off' % s) 

1781 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

1782 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

1783 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1784 

1785 try: 

1786 v[0] 

1787 except IndexError: 

1788 xmin = kwargs.get('xmin', None) 

1789 xmax = kwargs.get('xmax', None) 

1790 auto = False # turn off autoscaling, unless... 

1791 if xmin is None and xmax is None: 

1792 auto = None # leave autoscaling state alone 

1793 xmin, xmax = self.set_xlim(xmin, xmax, emit=emit, auto=auto) 

1794 

1795 ymin = kwargs.get('ymin', None) 

1796 ymax = kwargs.get('ymax', None) 

1797 auto = False # turn off autoscaling, unless... 

1798 if ymin is None and ymax is None: 

1799 auto = None # leave autoscaling state alone 

1800 ymin, ymax = self.set_ylim(ymin, ymax, emit=emit, auto=auto) 

1801 return xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax 

1802 

1803 v = v[0] 

1804 if len(v) != 4: 

1805 raise ValueError('v must contain [xmin xmax ymin ymax]') 

1806 

1807 self.set_xlim([v[0], v[1]], emit=emit, auto=False) 

1808 self.set_ylim([v[2], v[3]], emit=emit, auto=False) 

1809 

1810 return v 

1811

1854 def _sci(self, im): 

1855 """ 

1856 helper for :func:`~matplotlib.pyplot.sci`; 

1857 do not use elsewhere. 

1858 """ 

1859 if isinstance(im, matplotlib.contour.ContourSet): 

1860 if im.collections[0] not in self.collections: 

1861 raise ValueError( 

1862 "ContourSet must be in current Axes") 

1863 elif im not in self.images and im not in self.collections: 

1864 raise ValueError( 

1865 "Argument must be an image, collection, or ContourSet in " 

1866 "this Axes") 

1867 self._current_image = im

1874 return self._current_image

1876 def has_data(self): 

1877 """ 

1878 Return *True* if any artists have been added to axes. 

1879 

1880 This should not be used to determine whether the *dataLim* 

1881 need to be updated, and may not actually be useful for 

1882 anything. 

1883 """ 

1884 return ( 

1885 len(self.collections) + 

1886 len(self.images) + 

1887 len(self.lines) + 

1888 len(self.patches)) > 0 

1889 

1890 def add_artist(self, a): 

1891 """Add any :class:`~matplotlib.artist.Artist` to the axes. 

1892 

1893 Use `add_artist` only for artists for which there is no dedicated 

1894 "add" method; and if necessary, use a method such as `update_datalim` 

1895 to manually update the dataLim if the artist is to be included in 

1896 autoscaling. 

1897 

1898 Returns the artist. 

1899 """ 

1900 a.axes = self 

1901 self.artists.append(a) 

1902 self._set_artist_props(a) 

1903 a.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1904 a._remove_method = lambda h: self.artists.remove(h) 

1905 self.stale = True 

1906 return a 

1907 

1908 def add_collection(self, collection, autolim=True): 

1909 """ 

1910 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.collections.Collection` instance 

1911 to the axes. 

1912 

1913 Returns the collection. 

1914 """ 

1915 label = collection.get_label() 

1916 if not label: 

1917 collection.set_label('_collection%d' % len(self.collections)) 

1918 self.collections.append(collection) 

1919 self._set_artist_props(collection) 

1920 

1921 if collection.get_clip_path() is None: 

1922 collection.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

1923 

1924 if autolim: 

1925 self.update_datalim(collection.get_datalim(self.transData)) 

1926 

1927 collection._remove_method = lambda h: self.collections.remove(h) 

1928 self.stale = True 

1929 return collection

1977 

1978 def _update_line_limits(self, line): 

1979 """ 

1980 Figures out the data limit of the given line, updating self.dataLim. 

1981 """ 

1982 path = line.get_path() 

1983 if path.vertices.size == 0: 

1984 return 

1985 

1986 line_trans = line.get_transform() 

1987 

1988 if line_trans == self.transData: 

1989 data_path = path 

1990 

1991 elif any(line_trans.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)): 

1992 # identify the transform to go from line's coordinates 

1993 # to data coordinates 

1994 trans_to_data = line_trans - self.transData 

1995 

1996 # if transData is affine we can use the cached non-affine component 

1997 # of line's path. (since the non-affine part of line_trans is 

1998 # entirely encapsulated in trans_to_data). 

1999 if self.transData.is_affine: 

2000 line_trans_path = line._get_transformed_path() 

2001 na_path, _ = line_trans_path.get_transformed_path_and_affine() 

2002 data_path = trans_to_data.transform_path_affine(na_path) 

2003 else: 

2004 data_path = trans_to_data.transform_path(path) 

2005 else: 

2006 # for backwards compatibility we update the dataLim with the 

2007 # coordinate range of the given path, even though the coordinate 

2008 # systems are completely different. This may occur in situations 

2009 # such as when ax.transAxes is passed through for absolute 

2010 # positioning. 

2011 data_path = path 

2012 

2013 if data_path.vertices.size > 0: 

2014 updatex, updatey = line_trans.contains_branch_seperately( 

2015 self.transData) 

2016 self.dataLim.update_from_path(data_path, 

2017 self.ignore_existing_data_limits, 

2018 updatex=updatex, 

2019 updatey=updatey) 

2020 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = False 

2021 

2022 def add_patch(self, p): 

2023 """ 

2024 Add a :class:`~matplotlib.patches.Patch` *p* to the list of 

2025 axes patches; the clipbox will be set to the Axes clipping 

2026 box. If the transform is not set, it will be set to 

2027 :attr:`transData`. 

2028 

2029 Returns the patch. 

2030 """ 

2031 

2032 self._set_artist_props(p) 

2033 if p.get_clip_path() is None: 

2034 p.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

2035 self._update_patch_limits(p) 

2036 self.patches.append(p) 

2037 p._remove_method = lambda h: self.patches.remove(h) 

2038 return p 

2039 

2040 def _update_patch_limits(self, patch): 

2041 """update the data limits for patch *p*""" 

2042 # hist can add zero height Rectangles, which is useful to keep 

2043 # the bins, counts and patches lined up, but it throws off log 

2044 # scaling. We'll ignore rects with zero height or width in 

2045 # the auto-scaling 

2046 

2047 # cannot check for '==0' since unitized data may not compare to zero 

2048 # issue #2150 - we update the limits if patch has non zero width 

2049 # or height. 

2050 if (isinstance(patch, mpatches.Rectangle) and 

2051 ((not patch.get_width()) and (not patch.get_height()))): 

2052 return 

2053 vertices = patch.get_path().vertices 

2054 if vertices.size > 0: 

2055 xys = patch.get_patch_transform().transform(vertices) 

2056 if patch.get_data_transform() != self.transData: 

2057 patch_to_data = (patch.get_data_transform() - 

2058 self.transData) 

2059 xys = patch_to_data.transform(xys) 

2060 

2061 updatex, updatey = patch.get_transform().\ 

2062 contains_branch_seperately(self.transData) 

2063 self.update_datalim(xys, updatex=updatex, 

2064 updatey=updatey) 

2065

2108 

2109 def relim(self, visible_only=False): 

2110 """ 

2111 Recompute the data limits based on current artists. If you want to 

2112 exclude invisible artists from the calculation, set 

2113 ``visible_only=True`` 

2114 

2115 At present, :class:`~matplotlib.collections.Collection` 

2116 instances are not supported. 

2117 """ 

2118 # Collections are deliberately not supported (yet); see 

2119 # the TODO note in artists.py. 

2120 self.dataLim.ignore(True) 

2121 self.dataLim.set_points(mtransforms.Bbox.null().get_points()) 

2122 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = True 

2123 

2124 for line in self.lines: 

2125 if not visible_only or line.get_visible(): 

2126 self._update_line_limits(line) 

2127 

2128 for p in self.patches: 

2129 if not visible_only or p.get_visible(): 

2130 self._update_patch_limits(p) 

2131 

2132 for image in self.images: 

2133 if not visible_only or image.get_visible(): 

2134 self._update_image_limits(image) 

2135 

2136 def update_datalim(self, xys, updatex=True, updatey=True): 

2137 """ 

2138 Update the data lim bbox with seq of xy tups or equiv. 2-D array 

2139 """ 

2140 # if no data is set currently, the bbox will ignore its 

2141 # limits and set the bound to be the bounds of the xydata. 

2142 # Otherwise, it will compute the bounds of it's current data 

2143 # and the data in xydata 

2144 xys = np.asarray(xys) 

2145 if not len(xys): 

2146 return 

2147 self.dataLim.update_from_data_xy(xys, self.ignore_existing_data_limits, 

2148 updatex=updatex, updatey=updatey) 

2149 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = False 

2150 

2151 def update_datalim_bounds(self, bounds): 

2152 """ 

2153 Update the datalim to include the given 

2154 :class:`~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox` *bounds* 

2155 """ 

2156 self.dataLim.set(mtransforms.Bbox.union([self.dataLim, bounds])) 

2157 

2158 def _process_unit_info(self, xdata=None, ydata=None, kwargs=None): 

2159 """Look for unit *kwargs* and update the axis instances as necessary""" 

2160 

2161 if self.xaxis is None or self.yaxis is None: 

2162 return 

2163 

2164 if xdata is not None: 

2165 # we only need to update if there is nothing set yet. 

2166 if not self.xaxis.have_units(): 

2167 self.xaxis.update_units(xdata) 

2168 

2169 if ydata is not None: 

2170 # we only need to update if there is nothing set yet. 

2171 if not self.yaxis.have_units(): 

2172 self.yaxis.update_units(ydata) 

2173 

2174 # process kwargs 2nd since these will override default units 

2175 if kwargs is not None: 

2176 xunits = kwargs.pop('xunits', self.xaxis.units) 

2177 if self.name == 'polar': 

2178 xunits = kwargs.pop('thetaunits', xunits) 

2179 if xunits != self.xaxis.units: 

2180 self.xaxis.set_units(xunits) 

2181 # If the units being set imply a different converter, 

2182 # we need to update. 

2183 if xdata is not None: 

2184 self.xaxis.update_units(xdata) 

2185 

2186 yunits = kwargs.pop('yunits', self.yaxis.units) 

2187 if self.name == 'polar': 

2188 yunits = kwargs.pop('runits', yunits) 

2189 if yunits != self.yaxis.units: 

2190 self.yaxis.set_units(yunits) 

2191 # If the units being set imply a different converter, 

2192 # we need to update. 

2193 if ydata is not None: 

2194 self.yaxis.update_units(ydata) 

2195 return kwargs

2259 @property 

2260 def use_sticky_edges(self): 

2261 """ 

2262 When autoscaling, whether to obey all `Artist.sticky_edges`. 

2263 

2264 Default is ``True``. 

2265 

2266 Setting this to ``False`` ensures that the specified margins 

2267 will be applied, even if the plot includes an image, for 

2268 example, which would otherwise force a view limit to coincide 

2269 with its data limit. 

2270 

2271 The changing this property does not change the plot until 

2272 `autoscale` or `autoscale_view` is called. 

2273 """ 

2274 return self._use_sticky_edges 

2275 

2276 @use_sticky_edges.setter 

2277 def use_sticky_edges(self, b): 

2278 self._use_sticky_edges = bool(b) 

2279 # No effect until next autoscaling, which will mark the axes as stale. 

2280 

2281 def set_xmargin(self, m): 

2282 """ 

2283 Set padding of X data limits prior to autoscaling. 

2284 

2285 *m* times the data interval will be added to each 

2286 end of that interval before it is used in autoscaling. 

2287 For example, if your data is in the range [0, 2], a factor of 

2288 ``m = 0.1`` will result in a range [-0.2, 2.2]. 

2289 

2290 Negative values -0.5 < m < 0 will result in clipping of the data range. 

2291 I.e. for a data range [0, 2], a factor of ``m = -0.1`` will result in 

2292 a range [0.2, 1.8]. 

2293 

2294 .. ACCEPTS: float greater than -0.5 

2295 

2296 Parameters 

2297 ---------- 

2298 m : float greater than -0.5 

2299 """ 

2300 if m <= -0.5: 

2301 raise ValueError("margin must be greater than -0.5") 

2302 self._xmargin = m 

2303 self.stale = True 

2304 

2305 def set_ymargin(self, m): 

2306 """ 

2307 Set padding of Y data limits prior to autoscaling. 

2308 

2309 *m* times the data interval will be added to each 

2310 end of that interval before it is used in autoscaling. 

2311 For example, if your data is in the range [0, 2], a factor of 

2312 ``m = 0.1`` will result in a range [-0.2, 2.2]. 

2313 

2314 Negative values -0.5 < m < 0 will result in clipping of the data range. 

2315 I.e. for a data range [0, 2], a factor of ``m = -0.1`` will result in 

2316 a range [0.2, 1.8]. 

2317 

2318 .. ACCEPTS: float greater than -0.5 

2319 

2320 Parameters 

2321 ---------- 

2322 m : float greater than -0.5 

2323 """ 

2324 if m <= -0.5: 

2325 raise ValueError("margin must be greater than -0.5") 

2326 self._ymargin = m 

2327 self.stale = True 

2328 

2329 def margins(self, *args, **kw): 

2330 """ 

2331 Set or retrieve autoscaling margins. 

2332 

2333 signatures:: 

2334 

2335 margins() 

2336 

2337 returns xmargin, ymargin 

2338 

2339 :: 

2340 

2341 margins(margin) 

2342 

2343 margins(xmargin, ymargin) 

2344 

2345 margins(x=xmargin, y=ymargin) 

2346 

2347 margins(..., tight=False) 

2348 

2349 All three forms above set the xmargin and ymargin parameters. 

2350 All keyword parameters are optional. A single argument 

2351 specifies both xmargin and ymargin. The padding added to the end of 

2352 each interval is *margin* times the data interval. The *margin* must 

2353 be a float in the range [0, 1]. 

2354 

2355 The *tight* parameter is passed to :meth:`autoscale_view` 

2356 , which is executed after a margin is changed; the default here is 

2357 *True*, on the assumption that when margins are specified, no 

2358 additional padding to match tick marks is usually desired. Setting 

2359 *tight* to *None* will preserve the previous setting. 

2360 

2361 Specifying any margin changes only the autoscaling; for example, 

2362 if *xmargin* is not None, then *xmargin* times the X data 

2363 interval will be added to each end of that interval before 

2364 it is used in autoscaling. 

2365 

2366 """ 

2367 if not args and not kw: 

2368 return self._xmargin, self._ymargin 

2369 

2370 tight = kw.pop('tight', True) 

2371 mx = kw.pop('x', None) 

2372 my = kw.pop('y', None) 

2373 if len(args) == 1: 

2374 mx = my = args[0] 

2375 elif len(args) == 2: 

2376 mx, my = args 

2377 elif len(args) > 2: 

2378 raise ValueError("more than two arguments were supplied") 

2379 if mx is not None: 

2380 self.set_xmargin(mx) 

2381 if my is not None: 

2382 self.set_ymargin(my) 

2383 

2384 scalex = (mx is not None) 

2385 scaley = (my is not None) 

2386 

2387 self.autoscale_view(tight=tight, scalex=scalex, scaley=scaley) 

2388 

2389 def set_rasterization_zorder(self, z): 

2390 """ 

2391 Parameters 

2392 ---------- 

2393 z : float or None 

2394 zorder below which artists are rasterized. ``None`` means that 

2395 artists do not get rasterized based on zorder. 

2396 

2397 .. ACCEPTS: float or None 

2398 """ 

2399 self._rasterization_zorder = z 

2400 self.stale = True 

2401 

2402 def get_rasterization_zorder(self): 

2403 """Return the zorder value below which artists will be rasterized.""" 

2404 return self._rasterization_zorder 

2405 

2406 def autoscale(self, enable=True, axis='both', tight=None): 

2407 """ 

2408 Autoscale the axis view to the data (toggle). 

2409 

2410 Convenience method for simple axis view autoscaling. 

2411 It turns autoscaling on or off, and then, 

2412 if autoscaling for either axis is on, it performs 

2413 the autoscaling on the specified axis or axes. 

2414 

2415 Parameters 

2416 ---------- 

2417 enable : bool or None, optional 

2418 True (default) turns autoscaling on, False turns it off. 

2419 None leaves the autoscaling state unchanged. 

2420 

2421 axis : ['both' | 'x' | 'y'], optional 

2422 which axis to operate on; default is 'both' 

2423 

2424 tight: bool or None, optional 

2425 If True, set view limits to data limits; 

2426 if False, let the locator and margins expand the view limits; 

2427 if None, use tight scaling if the only artist is an image, 

2428 otherwise treat *tight* as False. 

2429 The *tight* setting is retained for future autoscaling 

2430 until it is explicitly changed. 

2431 

2432 """ 

2433 if enable is None: 

2434 scalex = True 

2435 scaley = True 

2436 else: 

2437 scalex = False 

2438 scaley = False 

2439 if axis in ['x', 'both']: 

2440 self._autoscaleXon = bool(enable) 

2441 scalex = self._autoscaleXon 

2442 if axis in ['y', 'both']: 

2443 self._autoscaleYon = bool(enable) 

2444 scaley = self._autoscaleYon 

2445 if tight and scalex: 

2446 self._xmargin = 0 

2447 if tight and scaley: 

2448 self._ymargin = 0 

2449 self.autoscale_view(tight=tight, scalex=scalex, scaley=scaley) 

2450 

2451 def autoscale_view(self, tight=None, scalex=True, scaley=True): 

2452 """ 

2453 Autoscale the view limits using the data limits. 

2454 

2455 You can selectively autoscale only a single axis, e.g., the xaxis by 

2456 setting *scaley* to *False*. The autoscaling preserves any 

2457 axis direction reversal that has already been done. 

2458 

2459 If *tight* is *False*, the axis major locator will be used 

2460 to expand the view limits if rcParams['axes.autolimit_mode'] 

2461 is 'round_numbers'. Note that any margins that are in effect 

2462 will be applied first, regardless of whether *tight* is 

2463 *True* or *False*. Specifying *tight* as *True* or *False* 

2464 saves the setting as a private attribute of the Axes; specifying 

2465 it as *None* (the default) applies the previously saved value. 

2466 

2467 The data limits are not updated automatically when artist data are 

2468 changed after the artist has been added to an Axes instance. In that 

2469 case, use :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.relim` prior to calling 

2470 autoscale_view. 

2471 """ 

2472 if tight is not None: 

2473 self._tight = bool(tight) 

2474 

2475 if self.use_sticky_edges and (self._xmargin or self._ymargin): 

2476 stickies = [artist.sticky_edges for artist in self.get_children()] 

2477 x_stickies = sum([sticky.x for sticky in stickies], []) 

2478 y_stickies = sum([sticky.y for sticky in stickies], []) 

2479 if self.get_xscale().lower() == 'log': 

2480 x_stickies = [xs for xs in x_stickies if xs > 0] 

2481 if self.get_yscale().lower() == 'log': 

2482 y_stickies = [ys for ys in y_stickies if ys > 0] 

2483 else: # Small optimization. 

2484 x_stickies, y_stickies = [], [] 

2485 

2486 def handle_single_axis(scale, autoscaleon, shared_axes, interval, 

2487 minpos, axis, margin, stickies, set_bound): 

2488 

2489 if not (scale and autoscaleon): 

2490 return # nothing to do... 

2491 

2492 shared = shared_axes.get_siblings(self) 

2493 dl = [ax.dataLim for ax in shared] 

2494 # ignore non-finite data limits if good limits exist 

2495 finite_dl = [d for d in dl if np.isfinite(d).all()] 

2496 if len(finite_dl): 

2497 # if finite limits exist for atleast one axis (and the 

2498 # other is infinite), restore the finite limits 

2499 x_finite = [d for d in dl 

2500 if (np.isfinite(d.intervalx).all() and 

2501 (d not in finite_dl))] 

2502 y_finite = [d for d in dl 

2503 if (np.isfinite(d.intervaly).all() and 

2504 (d not in finite_dl))] 

2505 

2506 dl = finite_dl 

2507 dl.extend(x_finite) 

2508 dl.extend(y_finite) 

2509 

2510 bb = mtransforms.BboxBase.union(dl) 

2511 x0, x1 = getattr(bb, interval) 

2512 locator = axis.get_major_locator() 

2513 try: 

2514 # e.g., DateLocator has its own nonsingular() 

2515 x0, x1 = locator.nonsingular(x0, x1) 

2516 except AttributeError: 

2517 # Default nonsingular for, e.g., MaxNLocator 

2518 x0, x1 = mtransforms.nonsingular( 

2519 x0, x1, increasing=False, expander=0.05) 

2520 

2521 # Add the margin in figure space and then transform back, to handle 

2522 # non-linear scales. 

2523 minpos = getattr(bb, minpos) 

2524 transform = axis.get_transform() 

2525 inverse_trans = transform.inverted() 

2526 # We cannot use exact equality due to floating point issues e.g. 

2527 # with streamplot. 

2528 do_lower_margin = not np.any(np.isclose(x0, stickies)) 

2529 do_upper_margin = not np.any(np.isclose(x1, stickies)) 

2530 x0, x1 = axis._scale.limit_range_for_scale(x0, x1, minpos) 

2531 x0t, x1t = transform.transform([x0, x1]) 

2532 delta = (x1t - x0t) * margin 

2533 if do_lower_margin: 

2534 x0t -= delta 

2535 if do_upper_margin: 

2536 x1t += delta 

2537 x0, x1 = inverse_trans.transform([x0t, x1t]) 

2538 

2539 if not self._tight: 

2540 x0, x1 = locator.view_limits(x0, x1) 

2541 set_bound(x0, x1) 

2542 # End of definition of internal function 'handle_single_axis'. 

2543 

2544 handle_single_axis( 

2545 scalex, self._autoscaleXon, self._shared_x_axes, 'intervalx', 

2546 'minposx', self.xaxis, self._xmargin, x_stickies, self.set_xbound) 

2547 handle_single_axis( 

2548 scaley, self._autoscaleYon, self._shared_y_axes, 'intervaly', 

2549 'minposy', self.yaxis, self._ymargin, y_stickies, self.set_ybound)

2551 def _get_axis_list(self): 

2552 return (self.xaxis, self.yaxis) 

2553 

2554 # Drawing 

2555 

2556 @allow_rasterization 

2557 def draw(self, renderer=None, inframe=False): 

2558 """Draw everything (plot lines, axes, labels)""" 

2559 if renderer is None: 

2560 renderer = self._cachedRenderer 

2561 

2562 if renderer is None: 

2563 raise RuntimeError('No renderer defined') 

2564 if not self.get_visible(): 

2565 return 

2566 renderer.open_group('axes') 

2567 # prevent triggering call backs during the draw process 

2568 self._stale = True 

2569 locator = self.get_axes_locator() 

2570 if locator: 

2571 pos = locator(self, renderer) 

2572 self.apply_aspect(pos) 

2573 else: 

2574 self.apply_aspect() 

2575 

2576 artists = self.get_children() 

2577 artists.remove(self.patch) 

2578 

2579 # the frame draws the edges around the axes patch -- we 

2580 # decouple these so the patch can be in the background and the 

2581 # frame in the foreground. Do this before drawing the axis 

2582 # objects so that the spine has the opportunity to update them. 

2583 if not (self.axison and self._frameon): 

2584 for spine in six.itervalues(self.spines): 

2585 artists.remove(spine) 

2586 

2587 if self.axison and not inframe: 

2588 if self._axisbelow is True: 

2589 self.xaxis.set_zorder(0.5) 

2590 self.yaxis.set_zorder(0.5) 

2591 elif self._axisbelow is False: 

2592 self.xaxis.set_zorder(2.5) 

2593 self.yaxis.set_zorder(2.5) 

2594 else: 

2595 # 'line': above patches, below lines 

2596 self.xaxis.set_zorder(1.5) 

2597 self.yaxis.set_zorder(1.5) 

2598 else: 

2599 for _axis in self._get_axis_list(): 

2600 artists.remove(_axis) 

2601 

2602 if inframe: 

2603 artists.remove(self.title) 

2604 artists.remove(self._left_title) 

2605 artists.remove(self._right_title) 

2606 

2607 if not self.figure.canvas.is_saving(): 

2608 artists = [a for a in artists 

2609 if not a.get_animated() or a in self.images] 

2610 artists = sorted(artists, key=attrgetter('zorder')) 

2611 

2612 # rasterize artists with negative zorder 

2613 # if the minimum zorder is negative, start rasterization 

2614 rasterization_zorder = self._rasterization_zorder 

2615 if (rasterization_zorder is not None and 

2616 artists and artists[0].zorder < rasterization_zorder): 

2617 renderer.start_rasterizing() 

2618 artists_rasterized = [a for a in artists 

2619 if a.zorder < rasterization_zorder] 

2620 artists = [a for a in artists 

2621 if a.zorder >= rasterization_zorder] 

2622 else: 

2623 artists_rasterized = [] 

2624 

2625 # the patch draws the background rectangle -- the frame below 

2626 # will draw the edges 

2627 if self.axison and self._frameon: 

2628 self.patch.draw(renderer) 

2629 

2630 if artists_rasterized: 

2631 for a in artists_rasterized: 

2632 a.draw(renderer) 

2633 renderer.stop_rasterizing() 

2634 

2635 mimage._draw_list_compositing_images(renderer, self, artists) 

2636 

2637 renderer.close_group('axes') 

2638 self._cachedRenderer = renderer 

2639 self.stale = False 

2640

2642 """ 

2643 This method can only be used after an initial draw which 

2644 caches the renderer. It is used to efficiently update Axes 

2645 data (axis ticks, labels, etc are not updated) 

2646 """ 

2647 if self._cachedRenderer is None: 

2648 raise AttributeError("draw_artist can only be used after an " 

2649 "initial draw which caches the renderer") 

2650 a.draw(self._cachedRenderer)

2654 This method can only be used after an initial draw which

2659 raise AttributeError("redraw_in_frame can only be used after an "

2706 @docstring.dedent_interpd 

2707 def grid(self, b=None, which='major', axis='both', **kwargs): 

2708 """ 

2709 Turn the axes grids on or off. 

2710 

2711 Set the axes grids on or off; *b* is a boolean. 

2712 

2713 If *b* is *None* and ``len(kwargs)==0``, toggle the grid state. If 

2714 *kwargs* are supplied, it is assumed that you want a grid and *b* 

2715 is thus set to *True*. 

2716 

2717 *which* can be 'major' (default), 'minor', or 'both' to control 

2718 whether major tick grids, minor tick grids, or both are affected. 

2719 

2720 *axis* can be 'both' (default), 'x', or 'y' to control which 

2721 set of gridlines are drawn. 

2722 

2723 *kwargs* are used to set the grid line properties, e.g.,:: 

2724 

2725 ax.grid(color='r', linestyle='-', linewidth=2) 

2726 

2727 Valid :class:`~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` kwargs are 

2728 

2729 %(Line2D)s 

2730 

2731 """ 

2732 if len(kwargs): 

2733 b = True 

2734 elif b is not None: 

2735 b = _string_to_bool(b) 

2736 

2737 if axis == 'x' or axis == 'both': 

2738 self.xaxis.grid(b, which=which, **kwargs) 

2739 if axis == 'y' or axis == 'both': 

2740 self.yaxis.grid(b, which=which, **kwargs)
