2742 def ticklabel_format(self, **kwargs): 

2743 """ 

2744 Change the `~matplotlib.ticker.ScalarFormatter` used by 

2745 default for linear axes. 

2746 

2747 Optional keyword arguments: 

2748 

2749 ============== ========================================= 

2750 Keyword Description 

2751 ============== ========================================= 

2752 *style* [ 'sci' (or 'scientific') | 'plain' ] 

2753 plain turns off scientific notation 

2754 *scilimits* (m, n), pair of integers; if *style* 

2755 is 'sci', scientific notation will 

2756 be used for numbers outside the range 

2757 10`m`:sup: to 10`n`:sup:. 

2758 Use (0,0) to include all numbers. 

2759 *useOffset* [ bool | offset ]; if True, 

2760 the offset will be calculated as needed; 

2761 if False, no offset will be used; if a 

2762 numeric offset is specified, it will be 

2763 used. 

2764 *axis* [ 'x' | 'y' | 'both' ] 

2765 *useLocale* If True, format the number according to 

2766 the current locale. This affects things 

2767 such as the character used for the 

2768 decimal separator. If False, use 

2769 C-style (English) formatting. The 

2770 default setting is controlled by the 

2771 axes.formatter.use_locale rcparam. 

2772 *useMathText* If True, render the offset and scientific 

2773 notation in mathtext 

2774 ============== ========================================= 

2775 

2776 Only the major ticks are affected. 

2777 If the method is called when the 

2778 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.ScalarFormatter` is not the 

2779 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.Formatter` being used, an 

2780 :exc:`AttributeError` will be raised. 

2781 

2782 """ 

2783 style = kwargs.pop('style', '').lower() 

2784 scilimits = kwargs.pop('scilimits', None) 

2785 useOffset = kwargs.pop('useOffset', None) 

2786 useLocale = kwargs.pop('useLocale', None) 

2787 useMathText = kwargs.pop('useMathText', None) 

2788 axis = kwargs.pop('axis', 'both').lower() 

2789 if scilimits is not None: 

2790 try: 

2791 m, n = scilimits 

2792 m + n + 1 # check that both are numbers 

2793 except (ValueError, TypeError): 

2794 raise ValueError("scilimits must be a sequence of 2 integers") 

2795 if style[:3] == 'sci': 

2796 sb = True 

2797 elif style == 'plain': 

2798 sb = False 

2799 elif style == 'comma': 

2800 raise NotImplementedError("comma style remains to be added") 

2801 elif style == '': 

2802 sb = None 

2803 else: 

2804 raise ValueError("%s is not a valid style value") 

2805 try: 

2806 if sb is not None: 

2807 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2808 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_scientific(sb) 

2809 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2810 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_scientific(sb) 

2811 if scilimits is not None: 

2812 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2813 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_powerlimits(scilimits) 

2814 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2815 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_powerlimits(scilimits) 

2816 if useOffset is not None: 

2817 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2818 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useOffset(useOffset) 

2819 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2820 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useOffset(useOffset) 

2821 if useLocale is not None: 

2822 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2823 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useLocale(useLocale) 

2824 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2825 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useLocale(useLocale) 

2826 if useMathText is not None: 

2827 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'x': 

2828 self.xaxis.major.formatter.set_useMathText(useMathText) 

2829 if axis == 'both' or axis == 'y': 

2830 self.yaxis.major.formatter.set_useMathText(useMathText) 

2831 except AttributeError: 

2832 raise AttributeError( 

2833 "This method only works with the ScalarFormatter.")

2835 def locator_params(self, axis='both', tight=None, **kwargs): 

2836 """ 

2837 Control behavior of tick locators. 

2838 

2839 Parameters 

2840 ---------- 

2841 axis : ['both' | 'x' | 'y'], optional 

2842 The axis on which to operate. 

2843 

2844 tight : bool or None, optional 

2845 Parameter passed to :meth:`autoscale_view`. 

2846 Default is None, for no change. 

2847 

2848 Other Parameters 

2849 ---------------- 

2850 **kw : 

2851 Remaining keyword arguments are passed to directly to the 

2852 :meth:`~matplotlib.ticker.MaxNLocator.set_params` method. 

2853 

2854 Typically one might want to reduce the maximum number 

2855 of ticks and use tight bounds when plotting small 

2856 subplots, for example:: 

2857 

2858 ax.locator_params(tight=True, nbins=4) 

2859 

2860 Because the locator is involved in autoscaling, 

2861 :meth:`autoscale_view` is called automatically after 

2862 the parameters are changed. 

2863 

2864 This presently works only for the 

2865 :class:`~matplotlib.ticker.MaxNLocator` used 

2866 by default on linear axes, but it may be generalized. 

2867 """ 

2868 _x = axis in ['x', 'both'] 

2869 _y = axis in ['y', 'both'] 

2870 if _x: 

2871 self.xaxis.get_major_locator().set_params(**kwargs) 

2872 if _y: 

2873 self.yaxis.get_major_locator().set_params(**kwargs) 

2874 self.autoscale_view(tight=tight, scalex=_x, scaley=_y)

2876 def tick_params(self, axis='both', **kwargs): 

2877 """Change the appearance of ticks, tick labels, and gridlines. 

2878 

2879 Parameters 

2880 ---------- 

2881 axis : {'x', 'y', 'both'}, optional 

2882 Which axis to apply the parameters to. 

2883 

2884 Other Parameters

2887 axis : {'x', 'y', 'both'} 

2888 Axis on which to operate; default is 'both'.

2891 If *True*, set all parameters to defaults 

2892 before processing other keyword arguments. Default is 

2893 *False*.

2896 Default is 'major'; apply arguments to *which* ticks. 

2897 

2898 direction : {'in', 'out', 'inout'} 

2899 Puts ticks inside the axes, outside the axes, or both. 

2900 

2901 length : float 

2902 Tick length in points. 

2903 

2904 width : float 

2905 Tick width in points. 

2906 

2907 color : color 

2908 Tick color; accepts any mpl color spec. 

2909 

2910 pad : float 

2911 Distance in points between tick and label. 

2912 

2913 labelsize : float or str 

2914 Tick label font size in points or as a string (e.g., 'large'). 

2915

2917 Tick label color; mpl color spec.

2953 grid_color='r', grid_alpha=0.5) 

2954 

2955 This will make all major ticks be red, pointing out of the box, 

2956 and with dimensions 6 points by 2 points. Tick labels will 

2957 also be red. Gridlines will be red and translucent. 

2958

2966 self.xaxis.set_tick_params(**xkw) 

2967 if axis in ['y', 'both']:

2969 ykw.pop('top', None)

2971 ykw.pop('labeltop', None) 

2972 ykw.pop('labelbottom', None)

2997 """Return the lower and upper x-axis bounds, in increasing order.""" 

2998 left, right = self.get_xlim() 

2999 if left < right: 

3000 return left, right 

3001 else: 

3002 return right, left

3004 def set_xbound(self, lower=None, upper=None): 

3005 """ 

3006 Set the lower and upper numerical bounds of the x-axis. 

3007 

3008 This method will honor axes inversion regardless of parameter order. 

3009 It will not change the _autoscaleXon attribute. 

3010 

3011 .. ACCEPTS: (lower: float, upper: float) 

3012 """ 

3013 if upper is None and iterable(lower): 

3014 lower, upper = lower 

3015 

3016 old_lower, old_upper = self.get_xbound() 

3017 

3018 if lower is None: 

3019 lower = old_lower 

3020 if upper is None: 

3021 upper = old_upper 

3022 

3023 if self.xaxis_inverted(): 

3024 if lower < upper: 

3025 self.set_xlim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3026 else: 

3027 self.set_xlim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3028 else: 

3029 if lower < upper: 

3030 self.set_xlim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3031 else: 

3032 self.set_xlim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3033 

3034 def get_xlim(self): 

3035 """ 

3036 Get the x-axis range 

3037 

3038 Returns 

3039 ------- 

3040 xlimits : tuple 

3041 Returns the current x-axis limits as the tuple 

3042 (`left`, `right`). 

3043 

3044 Notes 

3045 ----- 

3046 The x-axis may be inverted, in which case the `left` value will 

3047 be greater than the `right` value. 

3048 

3049 """ 

3050 return tuple(self.viewLim.intervalx) 

3051 

3052 def _validate_converted_limits(self, limit, convert): 

3053 """ 

3054 Raise ValueError if converted limits are non-finite. 

3055 

3056 Note that this function also accepts None as a limit argument. 

3057 

3058 Returns 

3059 ------- 

3060 The limit value after call to convert(), or None if limit is None. 

3061 

3062 """ 

3063 if limit is not None: 

3064 converted_limit = convert(limit) 

3065 if (isinstance(converted_limit, float) and 

3066 (not np.isreal(converted_limit) or 

3067 not np.isfinite(converted_limit))): 

3068 raise ValueError("Axis limits cannot be NaN or Inf") 

3069 return converted_limit 

3070 

3071 def set_xlim(self, left=None, right=None, emit=True, auto=False, **kw): 

3072 """ 

3073 Set the data limits for the x-axis 

3074 

3075 .. ACCEPTS: (left: float, right: float) 

3076 

3077 Parameters 

3078 ---------- 

3079 left : scalar, optional 

3080 The left xlim (default: None, which leaves the left limit 

3081 unchanged). 

3082 

3083 right : scalar, optional 

3084 The right xlim (default: None, which leaves the right limit 

3085 unchanged). 

3086 

3087 emit : bool, optional 

3088 Whether to notify observers of limit change (default: True). 

3089 

3090 auto : bool or None, optional 

3091 Whether to turn on autoscaling of the x-axis. True turns on, 

3092 False turns off (default action), None leaves unchanged. 

3093 

3094 xlimits : tuple, optional 

3095 The left and right xlims may be passed as the tuple 

3096 (`left`, `right`) as the first positional argument (or as 

3097 the `left` keyword argument). 

3098 

3099 Returns 

3100 ------- 

3101 xlimits : tuple 

3102 Returns the new x-axis limits as (`left`, `right`). 

3103 

3104 Notes 

3105 ----- 

3106 The `left` value may be greater than the `right` value, in which 

3107 case the x-axis values will decrease from left to right. 

3108 

3109 Examples 

3110 -------- 

3111 >>> set_xlim(left, right) 

3112 >>> set_xlim((left, right)) 

3113 >>> left, right = set_xlim(left, right) 

3114 

3115 One limit may be left unchanged. 

3116 

3117 >>> set_xlim(right=right_lim) 

3118 

3119 Limits may be passed in reverse order to flip the direction of 

3120 the x-axis. For example, suppose `x` represents the number of 

3121 years before present. The x-axis limits might be set like the 

3122 following so 5000 years ago is on the left of the plot and the 

3123 present is on the right. 

3124 

3125 >>> set_xlim(5000, 0) 

3126 

3127 """ 

3128 if 'xmin' in kw: 

3129 left = kw.pop('xmin') 

3130 if 'xmax' in kw: 

3131 right = kw.pop('xmax') 

3132 if kw: 

3133 raise ValueError("unrecognized kwargs: %s" % list(kw)) 

3134 

3135 if right is None and iterable(left): 

3136 left, right = left 

3137 

3138 self._process_unit_info(xdata=(left, right)) 

3139 left = self._validate_converted_limits(left, self.convert_xunits) 

3140 right = self._validate_converted_limits(right, self.convert_xunits) 

3141 

3142 old_left, old_right = self.get_xlim() 

3143 if left is None: 

3144 left = old_left 

3145 if right is None: 

3146 right = old_right 

3147 

3148 if left == right: 

3149 warnings.warn( 

3150 ('Attempting to set identical left==right results\n' 

3151 'in singular transformations; automatically expanding.\n' 

3152 'left=%s, right=%s') % (left, right)) 

3153 left, right = mtransforms.nonsingular(left, right, increasing=False) 

3154 

3155 if self.get_xscale() == 'log' and (left <= 0.0 or right <= 0.0): 

3156 warnings.warn( 

3157 'Attempted to set non-positive xlimits for log-scale axis; ' 

3158 'invalid limits will be ignored.') 

3159 left, right = self.xaxis.limit_range_for_scale(left, right) 

3160 

3161 self.viewLim.intervalx = (left, right) 

3162 if auto is not None: 

3163 self._autoscaleXon = bool(auto) 

3164 

3165 if emit: 

3166 self.callbacks.process('xlim_changed', self) 

3167 # Call all of the other x-axes that are shared with this one 

3168 for other in self._shared_x_axes.get_siblings(self): 

3169 if other is not self: 

3170 other.set_xlim(self.viewLim.intervalx, 

3171 emit=False, auto=auto) 

3172 if (other.figure != self.figure and 

3173 other.figure.canvas is not None): 

3174 other.figure.canvas.draw_idle() 

3175 self.stale = True 

3176 return left, right 

3177 

3178 def get_xscale(self): 

3179 return self.xaxis.get_scale() 

3180 get_xscale.__doc__ = "Return the xaxis scale string: %s""" % ( 

3181 ", ".join(mscale.get_scale_names())) 

3182 

3183 def set_xscale(self, value, **kwargs): 

3184 """ 

3185 Set the x-axis scale. 

3186 

3187 .. ACCEPTS: [ 'linear' | 'log' | 'symlog' | 'logit' | ... ] 

3188 

3189 Parameters 

3190 ---------- 

3191 value : {"linear", "log", "symlog", "logit"} 

3192 scaling strategy to apply 

3193 

3194 Notes 

3195 ----- 

3196 Different kwargs are accepted, depending on the scale. See 

3197 the `~matplotlib.scale` module for more information. 

3198 

3199 See also 

3200 -------- 

3201 matplotlib.scale.LinearScale : linear transform 

3202 

3203 matplotlib.scale.LogTransform : log transform 

3204 

3205 matplotlib.scale.SymmetricalLogTransform : symlog transform 

3206 

3207 matplotlib.scale.LogisticTransform : logit transform 

3208 """ 

3209 g = self.get_shared_x_axes() 

3210 for ax in g.get_siblings(self): 

3211 ax.xaxis._set_scale(value, **kwargs) 

3212 ax._update_transScale() 

3213 ax.stale = True 

3214 

3215 self.autoscale_view(scaley=False)

3327 def invert_yaxis(self): 

3328 """Invert the y-axis.""" 

3329 self.set_ylim(self.get_ylim()[::-1], auto=None) 

3330 

3331 def yaxis_inverted(self): 

3332 """Return whether the y-axis is inverted.""" 

3333 bottom, top = self.get_ylim() 

3334 return top < bottom 

3335 

3336 def get_ybound(self): 

3337 """Return the lower and upper y-axis bounds, in increasing order.""" 

3338 bottom, top = self.get_ylim() 

3339 if bottom < top: 

3340 return bottom, top 

3341 else: 

3342 return top, bottom 

3343 

3344 def set_ybound(self, lower=None, upper=None): 

3345 """ 

3346 Set the lower and upper numerical bounds of the y-axis. 

3347 This method will honor axes inversion regardless of parameter order. 

3348 It will not change the _autoscaleYon attribute. 

3349 

3350 .. ACCEPTS: (lower: float, upper: float) 

3351 """ 

3352 if upper is None and iterable(lower): 

3353 lower, upper = lower 

3354 

3355 old_lower, old_upper = self.get_ybound() 

3356 

3357 if lower is None: 

3358 lower = old_lower 

3359 if upper is None: 

3360 upper = old_upper 

3361 

3362 if self.yaxis_inverted(): 

3363 if lower < upper: 

3364 self.set_ylim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3365 else: 

3366 self.set_ylim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3367 else: 

3368 if lower < upper: 

3369 self.set_ylim(lower, upper, auto=None) 

3370 else: 

3371 self.set_ylim(upper, lower, auto=None) 

3372 

3373 def get_ylim(self): 

3374 """ 

3375 Get the y-axis range 

3376 

3377 Returns 

3378 ------- 

3379 ylimits : tuple 

3380 Returns the current y-axis limits as the tuple 

3381 (`bottom`, `top`). 

3382 

3383 Notes 

3384 ----- 

3385 The y-axis may be inverted, in which case the `bottom` value 

3386 will be greater than the `top` value. 

3387 

3388 """ 

3389 return tuple(self.viewLim.intervaly) 

3390 

3391 def set_ylim(self, bottom=None, top=None, emit=True, auto=False, **kw): 

3392 """ 

3393 Set the data limits for the y-axis 

3394 

3395 .. ACCEPTS: (bottom: float, top: float) 

3396 

3397 Parameters 

3398 ---------- 

3399 bottom : scalar, optional 

3400 The bottom ylim (default: None, which leaves the bottom 

3401 limit unchanged). 

3402 

3403 top : scalar, optional 

3404 The top ylim (default: None, which leaves the top limit 

3405 unchanged). 

3406 

3407 emit : bool, optional 

3408 Whether to notify observers of limit change (default: True). 

3409 

3410 auto : bool or None, optional 

3411 Whether to turn on autoscaling of the y-axis. True turns on, 

3412 False turns off (default action), None leaves unchanged. 

3413 

3414 ylimits : tuple, optional 

3415 The bottom and top yxlims may be passed as the tuple 

3416 (`bottom`, `top`) as the first positional argument (or as 

3417 the `bottom` keyword argument). 

3418 

3419 Returns 

3420 ------- 

3421 ylimits : tuple 

3422 Returns the new y-axis limits as (`bottom`, `top`). 

3423 

3424 Notes 

3425 ----- 

3426 The `bottom` value may be greater than the `top` value, in which 

3427 case the y-axis values will decrease from bottom to top. 

3428 

3429 Examples 

3430 -------- 

3431 >>> set_ylim(bottom, top) 

3432 >>> set_ylim((bottom, top)) 

3433 >>> bottom, top = set_ylim(bottom, top) 

3434 

3435 One limit may be left unchanged. 

3436 

3437 >>> set_ylim(top=top_lim) 

3438 

3439 Limits may be passed in reverse order to flip the direction of 

3440 the y-axis. For example, suppose `y` represents depth of the 

3441 ocean in m. The y-axis limits might be set like the following 

3442 so 5000 m depth is at the bottom of the plot and the surface, 

3443 0 m, is at the top. 

3444 

3445 >>> set_ylim(5000, 0) 

3446 """ 

3447 if 'ymin' in kw: 

3448 bottom = kw.pop('ymin') 

3449 if 'ymax' in kw: 

3450 top = kw.pop('ymax') 

3451 if kw: 

3452 raise ValueError("unrecognized kwargs: %s" % list(kw)) 

3453 

3454 if top is None and iterable(bottom): 

3455 bottom, top = bottom 

3456 

3457 bottom = self._validate_converted_limits(bottom, self.convert_yunits) 

3458 top = self._validate_converted_limits(top, self.convert_yunits) 

3459 

3460 old_bottom, old_top = self.get_ylim() 

3461 

3462 if bottom is None: 

3463 bottom = old_bottom 

3464 if top is None: 

3465 top = old_top 

3466 

3467 if bottom == top: 

3468 warnings.warn( 

3469 ('Attempting to set identical bottom==top results\n' 

3470 'in singular transformations; automatically expanding.\n' 

3471 'bottom=%s, top=%s') % (bottom, top)) 

3472 

3473 bottom, top = mtransforms.nonsingular(bottom, top, increasing=False) 

3474 

3475 if self.get_yscale() == 'log' and (bottom <= 0.0 or top <= 0.0): 

3476 warnings.warn( 

3477 'Attempted to set non-positive ylimits for log-scale axis; ' 

3478 'invalid limits will be ignored.') 

3479 bottom, top = self.yaxis.limit_range_for_scale(bottom, top) 

3480 

3481 self.viewLim.intervaly = (bottom, top) 

3482 if auto is not None: 

3483 self._autoscaleYon = bool(auto) 

3484 

3485 if emit: 

3486 self.callbacks.process('ylim_changed', self) 

3487 # Call all of the other y-axes that are shared with this one 

3488 for other in self._shared_y_axes.get_siblings(self): 

3489 if other is not self: 

3490 other.set_ylim(self.viewLim.intervaly, 

3491 emit=False, auto=auto) 

3492 if (other.figure != self.figure and 

3493 other.figure.canvas is not None): 

3494 other.figure.canvas.draw_idle() 

3495 self.stale = True 

3496 return bottom, top 

3497 

3498 def get_yscale(self): 

3499 return self.yaxis.get_scale() 

3500 get_yscale.__doc__ = "Return the yaxis scale string: %s""" % ( 

3501 ", ".join(mscale.get_scale_names()))

3667 def format_xdata(self, x): 

3668 """ 

3669 Return *x* string formatted. This function will use the attribute 

3670 self.fmt_xdata if it is callable, else will fall back on the xaxis 

3671 major formatter 

3672 """ 

3673 try: 

3674 return self.fmt_xdata(x) 

3675 except TypeError: 

3676 func = self.xaxis.get_major_formatter().format_data_short 

3677 val = func(x) 

3678 return val

3681 """

3684 back on the yaxis major formatter 

3685 """ 

3686 try:

3692 

3693 def format_coord(self, x, y): 

3694 """Return a format string formatting the *x*, *y* coord""" 

3695 if x is None: 

3696 xs = '???' 

3697 else: 

3698 xs = self.format_xdata(x) 

3699 if y is None: 

3700 ys = '???' 

3701 else: 

3702 ys = self.format_ydata(y) 

3703 return 'x=%s y=%s' % (xs, ys) 

3704 

3705 def minorticks_on(self): 

3706 'Add autoscaling minor ticks to the axes.' 

3707 for ax in (self.xaxis, self.yaxis): 

3708 scale = ax.get_scale() 

3709 if scale == 'log': 

3710 s = ax._scale 

3711 ax.set_minor_locator(mticker.LogLocator(s.base, s.subs)) 

3712 elif scale == 'symlog': 

3713 s = ax._scale 

3714 ax.set_minor_locator( 

3715 mticker.SymmetricalLogLocator(s._transform, s.subs)) 

3716 else: 

3717 ax.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator()) 

3718 

3719 def minorticks_off(self): 

3720 """Remove minor ticks from the axes.""" 

3721 self.xaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.NullLocator()) 

3722 self.yaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.NullLocator())

3772 def _get_view(self): 

3773 """ 

3774 Save information required to reproduce the current view. 

3775 

3776 Called before a view is changed, such as during a pan or zoom 

3777 initiated by the user. You may return any information you deem 

3778 necessary to describe the view. 

3779 

3780 .. note:: 

3781 

3782 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3783 default implementation saves the view limits. You *must* implement 

3784 :meth:`_set_view` if you implement this method. 

3785 """ 

3786 xmin, xmax = self.get_xlim() 

3787 ymin, ymax = self.get_ylim() 

3788 return (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) 

3789 

3790 def _set_view(self, view): 

3791 """ 

3792 Apply a previously saved view. 

3793 

3794 Called when restoring a view, such as with the navigation buttons. 

3795 

3796 .. note:: 

3797 

3798 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3799 default implementation restores the view limits. You *must* 

3800 implement :meth:`_get_view` if you implement this method. 

3801 """ 

3802 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = view 

3803 self.set_xlim((xmin, xmax)) 

3804 self.set_ylim((ymin, ymax)) 

3805 

3806 def _set_view_from_bbox(self, bbox, direction='in', 

3807 mode=None, twinx=False, twiny=False): 

3808 """ 

3809 Update view from a selection bbox. 

3810 

3811 .. note:: 

3812 

3813 Intended to be overridden by new projection types, but if not, the 

3814 default implementation sets the view limits to the bbox directly. 

3815 

3816 Parameters 

3817 ---------- 

3818 

3819 bbox : 4-tuple or 3 tuple 

3820 * If bbox is a 4 tuple, it is the selected bounding box limits, 

3821 in *display* coordinates. 

3822 * If bbox is a 3 tuple, it is an (xp, yp, scl) triple, where 

3823 (xp,yp) is the center of zooming and scl the scale factor to 

3824 zoom by. 

3825 

3826 direction : str 

3827 The direction to apply the bounding box. 

3828 * `'in'` - The bounding box describes the view directly, i.e., 

3829 it zooms in. 

3830 * `'out'` - The bounding box describes the size to make the 

3831 existing view, i.e., it zooms out. 

3832 

3833 mode : str or None 

3834 The selection mode, whether to apply the bounding box in only the 

3835 `'x'` direction, `'y'` direction or both (`None`). 

3836 

3837 twinx : bool 

3838 Whether this axis is twinned in the *x*-direction. 

3839 

3840 twiny : bool 

3841 Whether this axis is twinned in the *y*-direction. 

3842 """ 

3843 Xmin, Xmax = self.get_xlim() 

3844 Ymin, Ymax = self.get_ylim() 

3845 

3846 if len(bbox) == 3: 

3847 # Zooming code 

3848 xp, yp, scl = bbox 

3849 

3850 # Should not happen 

3851 if scl == 0: 

3852 scl = 1. 

3853 

3854 # direction = 'in' 

3855 if scl > 1: 

3856 direction = 'in' 

3857 else: 

3858 direction = 'out' 

3859 scl = 1/scl 

3860 

3861 # get the limits of the axes 

3862 tranD2C = self.transData.transform 

3863 xmin, ymin = tranD2C((Xmin, Ymin)) 

3864 xmax, ymax = tranD2C((Xmax, Ymax)) 

3865 

3866 # set the range 

3867 xwidth = xmax - xmin 

3868 ywidth = ymax - ymin 

3869 xcen = (xmax + xmin)*.5 

3870 ycen = (ymax + ymin)*.5 

3871 xzc = (xp*(scl - 1) + xcen)/scl 

3872 yzc = (yp*(scl - 1) + ycen)/scl 

3873 

3874 bbox = [xzc - xwidth/2./scl, yzc - ywidth/2./scl, 

3875 xzc + xwidth/2./scl, yzc + ywidth/2./scl] 

3876 elif len(bbox) != 4: 

3877 # should be len 3 or 4 but nothing else 

3878 warnings.warn( 

3879 "Warning in _set_view_from_bbox: bounding box is not a tuple " 

3880 "of length 3 or 4. Ignoring the view change.") 

3881 return 

3882 

3883 # Just grab bounding box 

3884 lastx, lasty, x, y = bbox 

3885 

3886 # zoom to rect 

3887 inverse = self.transData.inverted() 

3888 lastx, lasty = inverse.transform_point((lastx, lasty)) 

3889 x, y = inverse.transform_point((x, y)) 

3890 

3891 if twinx: 

3892 x0, x1 = Xmin, Xmax 

3893 else: 

3894 if Xmin < Xmax: 

3895 if x < lastx: 

3896 x0, x1 = x, lastx 

3897 else: 

3898 x0, x1 = lastx, x 

3899 if x0 < Xmin: 

3900 x0 = Xmin 

3901 if x1 > Xmax: 

3902 x1 = Xmax 

3903 else: 

3904 if x > lastx: 

3905 x0, x1 = x, lastx 

3906 else: 

3907 x0, x1 = lastx, x 

3908 if x0 > Xmin: 

3909 x0 = Xmin 

3910 if x1 < Xmax: 

3911 x1 = Xmax 

3912 

3913 if twiny: 

3914 y0, y1 = Ymin, Ymax 

3915 else: 

3916 if Ymin < Ymax: 

3917 if y < lasty: 

3918 y0, y1 = y, lasty 

3919 else: 

3920 y0, y1 = lasty, y 

3921 if y0 < Ymin: 

3922 y0 = Ymin 

3923 if y1 > Ymax: 

3924 y1 = Ymax 

3925 else: 

3926 if y > lasty: 

3927 y0, y1 = y, lasty 

3928 else: 

3929 y0, y1 = lasty, y 

3930 if y0 > Ymin: 

3931 y0 = Ymin 

3932 if y1 < Ymax: 

3933 y1 = Ymax 

3934 

3935 if direction == 'in': 

3936 if mode == 'x': 

3937 self.set_xlim((x0, x1)) 

3938 elif mode == 'y': 

3939 self.set_ylim((y0, y1)) 

3940 else: 

3941 self.set_xlim((x0, x1)) 

3942 self.set_ylim((y0, y1)) 

3943 elif direction == 'out': 

3944 if self.get_xscale() == 'log': 

3945 alpha = np.log(Xmax / Xmin) / np.log(x1 / x0) 

3946 rx1 = pow(Xmin / x0, alpha) * Xmin 

3947 rx2 = pow(Xmax / x0, alpha) * Xmin 

3948 else: 

3949 alpha = (Xmax - Xmin) / (x1 - x0) 

3950 rx1 = alpha * (Xmin - x0) + Xmin 

3951 rx2 = alpha * (Xmax - x0) + Xmin 

3952 if self.get_yscale() == 'log': 

3953 alpha = np.log(Ymax / Ymin) / np.log(y1 / y0) 

3954 ry1 = pow(Ymin / y0, alpha) * Ymin 

3955 ry2 = pow(Ymax / y0, alpha) * Ymin 

3956 else: 

3957 alpha = (Ymax - Ymin) / (y1 - y0) 

3958 ry1 = alpha * (Ymin - y0) + Ymin 

3959 ry2 = alpha * (Ymax - y0) + Ymin 

3960 

3961 if mode == 'x': 

3962 self.set_xlim((rx1, rx2)) 

3963 elif mode == 'y': 

3964 self.set_ylim((ry1, ry2)) 

3965 else: 

3966 self.set_xlim((rx1, rx2)) 

3967 self.set_ylim((ry1, ry2)) 

3968 

3969 def start_pan(self, x, y, button): 

3970 """ 

3971 Called when a pan operation has started. 

3972 

3973 *x*, *y* are the mouse coordinates in display coords. 

3974 button is the mouse button number: 

3975 

3976 * 1: LEFT 

3977 * 2: MIDDLE 

3978 * 3: RIGHT 

3979 

3980 .. note:: 

3981 

3982 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

3983 

3984 """ 

3985 self._pan_start = cbook.Bunch( 

3986 lim=self.viewLim.frozen(), 

3987 trans=self.transData.frozen(), 

3988 trans_inverse=self.transData.inverted().frozen(), 

3989 bbox=self.bbox.frozen(), 

3990 x=x, 

3991 y=y) 

3992 

3993 def end_pan(self): 

3994 """ 

3995 Called when a pan operation completes (when the mouse button 

3996 is up.) 

3997 

3998 .. note:: 

3999 

4000 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

4001 

4002 """ 

4003 del self._pan_start 

4004 

4005 def drag_pan(self, button, key, x, y): 

4006 """ 

4007 Called when the mouse moves during a pan operation. 

4008 

4009 *button* is the mouse button number: 

4010 

4011 * 1: LEFT 

4012 * 2: MIDDLE 

4013 * 3: RIGHT 

4014 

4015 *key* is a "shift" key 

4016 

4017 *x*, *y* are the mouse coordinates in display coords. 

4018 

4019 .. note:: 

4020 

4021 Intended to be overridden by new projection types. 

4022 

4023 """ 

4024 def format_deltas(key, dx, dy): 

4025 if key == 'control': 

4026 if abs(dx) > abs(dy): 

4027 dy = dx 

4028 else: 

4029 dx = dy 

4030 elif key == 'x': 

4031 dy = 0 

4032 elif key == 'y': 

4033 dx = 0 

4034 elif key == 'shift': 

4035 if 2 * abs(dx) < abs(dy): 

4036 dx = 0 

4037 elif 2 * abs(dy) < abs(dx): 

4038 dy = 0 

4039 elif abs(dx) > abs(dy): 

4040 dy = dy / abs(dy) * abs(dx) 

4041 else: 

4042 dx = dx / abs(dx) * abs(dy) 

4043 return dx, dy 

4044 

4045 p = self._pan_start 

4046 dx = x - p.x 

4047 dy = y - p.y 

4048 if dx == 0 and dy == 0: 

4049 return 

4050 if button == 1: 

4051 dx, dy = format_deltas(key, dx, dy) 

4052 result = p.bbox.translated(-dx, -dy).transformed(p.trans_inverse) 

4053 elif button == 3: 

4054 try: 

4055 dx = -dx / self.bbox.width 

4056 dy = -dy / self.bbox.height 

4057 dx, dy = format_deltas(key, dx, dy) 

4058 if self.get_aspect() != 'auto': 

4059 dx = dy = 0.5 * (dx + dy) 

4060 alpha = np.power(10.0, (dx, dy)) 

4061 start = np.array([p.x, p.y]) 

4062 oldpoints = p.lim.transformed(p.trans) 

4063 newpoints = start + alpha * (oldpoints - start) 

4064 result = (mtransforms.Bbox(newpoints) 

4065 .transformed(p.trans_inverse)) 

4066 except OverflowError: 

4067 warnings.warn('Overflow while panning') 

4068 return 

4069 

4070 valid = np.isfinite(result.transformed(p.trans)) 

4071 points = result.get_points().astype(object) 

4072 # Just ignore invalid limits (typically, underflow in log-scale). 

4073 points[~valid] = None 

4074 self.set_xlim(points[:, 0]) 

4075 self.set_ylim(points[:, 1]) 

4076 

4077 @cbook.deprecated("2.1") 

4078 def get_cursor_props(self): 

4079 """ 

4080 Return the cursor propertiess as a (*linewidth*, *color*) 

4081 tuple, where *linewidth* is a float and *color* is an RGBA 

4082 tuple 

4083 """ 

4084 return self._cursorProps 

4085 

4086 @cbook.deprecated("2.1") 

4087 def set_cursor_props(self, *args): 

4088 """Set the cursor property as 

4089 

4090 Call signature :: 

4091 

4092 ax.set_cursor_props(linewidth, color) 

4093 

4094 or:: 

4095 

4096 ax.set_cursor_props((linewidth, color)) 

4097 

4098 ACCEPTS: a (*float*, *color*) tuple 

4099 """ 

4100 if len(args) == 1: 

4101 lw, c = args[0] 

4102 elif len(args) == 2: 

4103 lw, c = args 

4104 else: 

4105 raise ValueError('args must be a (linewidth, color) tuple') 

4106 c = mcolors.to_rgba(c) 

4107 self._cursorProps = lw, c

4109 def get_children(self): 

4110 """return a list of child artists""" 

4111 children = [] 

4112 children.extend(self.collections) 

4113 children.extend(self.patches) 

4114 children.extend(self.lines) 

4115 children.extend(self.texts) 

4116 children.extend(self.artists) 

4117 children.extend(six.itervalues(self.spines)) 

4118 children.append(self.xaxis) 

4119 children.append(self.yaxis) 

4120 children.append(self.title) 

4121 children.append(self._left_title) 

4122 children.append(self._right_title) 

4123 children.extend(self.tables) 

4124 children.extend(self.images) 

4125 if self.legend_ is not None: 

4126 children.append(self.legend_) 

4127 children.append(self.patch) 

4128 return children

4165 def get_tightbbox(self, renderer, call_axes_locator=True): 

4166 """ 

4167 Return the tight bounding box of the axes. 

4168 The dimension of the Bbox in canvas coordinate. 

4169 

4170 If *call_axes_locator* is *False*, it does not call the 

4171 _axes_locator attribute, which is necessary to get the correct 

4172 bounding box. ``call_axes_locator==False`` can be used if the 

4173 caller is only intereted in the relative size of the tightbbox 

4174 compared to the axes bbox. 

4175 """ 

4176 

4177 bb = [] 

4178 

4179 if not self.get_visible(): 

4180 return None 

4181 

4182 locator = self.get_axes_locator() 

4183 if locator and call_axes_locator: 

4184 pos = locator(self, renderer) 

4185 self.apply_aspect(pos) 

4186 else: 

4187 self.apply_aspect() 

4188 

4189 bb.append(self.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4190 

4191 if self.title.get_visible(): 

4192 bb.append(self.title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4193 if self._left_title.get_visible(): 

4194 bb.append(self._left_title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4195 if self._right_title.get_visible(): 

4196 bb.append(self._right_title.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4197 

4198 bb_xaxis = self.xaxis.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

4199 if bb_xaxis: 

4200 bb.append(bb_xaxis) 

4201 

4202 bb_yaxis = self.yaxis.get_tightbbox(renderer) 

4203 if bb_yaxis: 

4204 bb.append(bb_yaxis) 

4205 

4206 for child in self.get_children(): 

4207 if isinstance(child, OffsetBox) and child.get_visible(): 

4208 bb.append(child.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4209 elif isinstance(child, Legend) and child.get_visible(): 

4210 bb.append(child._legend_box.get_window_extent(renderer)) 

4211 

4212 _bbox = mtransforms.Bbox.union( 

4213 [b for b in bb if b.width != 0 or b.height != 0]) 

4214 

4215 return _bbox

4217 def _make_twin_axes(self, *kl, **kwargs): 

4218 """ 

4219 Make a twinx axes of self. This is used for twinx and twiny. 

4220 """ 

4221 # Typically, SubplotBase._make_twin_axes is called instead of this. 

4222 # There is also an override in axes_grid1/axes_divider.py. 

4223 if 'sharex' in kwargs and 'sharey' in kwargs: 

4224 raise ValueError("Twinned Axes may share only one axis.") 

4225 ax2 = self.figure.add_axes(self.get_position(True), *kl, **kwargs) 

4226 self.set_adjustable('datalim') 

4227 ax2.set_adjustable('datalim') 

4228 self._twinned_axes.join(self, ax2) 

4229 return ax2 

4230 

4231 def twinx(self): 

4232 """ 

4233 Create a twin Axes sharing the xaxis 

4234 

4235 Create a new Axes instance with an invisible x-axis and an independent 

4236 y-axis positioned opposite to the original one (i.e. at right). The 

4237 x-axis autoscale setting will be inherited from the original Axes. 

4238 To ensure that the tick marks of both y-axes align, see 

4239 `~matplotlib.ticker.LinearLocator` 

4240 

4241 Returns 

4242 ------- 

4243 ax_twin : Axes 

4244 The newly created Axes instance 

4245 

4246 Notes 

4247 ----- 

4248 For those who are 'picking' artists while using twinx, pick 

4249 events are only called for the artists in the top-most axes. 

4250 """ 

4251 ax2 = self._make_twin_axes(sharex=self) 

4252 ax2.yaxis.tick_right() 

4253 ax2.yaxis.set_label_position('right') 

4254 ax2.yaxis.set_offset_position('right') 

4255 ax2.set_autoscalex_on(self.get_autoscalex_on()) 

4256 self.yaxis.tick_left() 

4257 ax2.xaxis.set_visible(False) 

4258 ax2.patch.set_visible(False) 

4259 return ax2 

4260 

4261 def twiny(self): 

4262 """ 

4263 Create a twin Axes sharing the yaxis 

4264 

4265 Create a new Axes instance with an invisible y-axis and an independent 

4266 x-axis positioned opposite to the original one (i.e. at top). The 

4267 y-axis autoscale setting will be inherited from the original Axes. 

4268 To ensure that the tick marks of both x-axes align, see 

4269 `~matplotlib.ticker.LinearLocator` 

4270 

4271 Returns 

4272 ------- 

4273 ax_twin : Axes 

4274 The newly created Axes instance 

4275 

4276 Notes 

4277 ----- 

4278 For those who are 'picking' artists while using twiny, pick 

4279 events are only called for the artists in the top-most axes. 

4280 """ 

4281 

4282 ax2 = self._make_twin_axes(sharey=self) 

4283 ax2.xaxis.tick_top() 

4284 ax2.xaxis.set_label_position('top') 

4285 ax2.set_autoscaley_on(self.get_autoscaley_on()) 

4286 self.xaxis.tick_bottom() 

4287 ax2.yaxis.set_visible(False) 

4288 ax2.patch.set_visible(False) 

4289 return ax2
